titleStmt.title: The Feign'd astrologer a comedie.
titleStmt.author: Calderón de la Barca, Pedro, 1600-1681. Astrologo fingido.
Corneille, Thomas, 1625-1709. Feint astrologue.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.
As adaption by an unknown translator of Thomas Corneille's "Le feint astrologue," which was founded on Calderon's "El astrologo fingido."

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Thomas Thornycroft, at the Eagle and Child, near Worcester-house in the Strand. 1668.

list.item: SIr Christopher Credulous— A Rich old Knight, father to Clarinda.
Bellamy— In Love with Clarinda, and belov'd by Celia.
Endimion— Once a Pretender to Clarinda.
Lewis Bernard— Friends to Endimion, and Gratian.
Celia— In Love with Bellamy, and belov'd by Gratian.
Fannie— A little Cosen of Celia's.
La-gripe— An old French man, a servant of Sr Christopher's.
Shift Rawman— Two wittie Knaves servants to Endimion.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: HOw strangely does thy News perplexme, Shift?
Art sure 'tis true?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Beatrix tells me so, and then I must believe it.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Is she your Oracle then?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But is it possible that my Clarinda should—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: No, that it is not, she should ever love,
You I mean; for there may be perhaps—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I guess the reason of her scorn,
She loves else where.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: E'en like enough.
She'd ne'r hold her self at so high a rate to you,
Had she not other Chapmen.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I smelt some such thing in a certain Conference, I had with my Princess to'ther day; and had not her doting old Master come by i'th nick and spoilt our sport, I was within two kisses of all her Mistresses secrets.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Is Beatrix such a tell-tale?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Tell-tale, and Wag-tail. Why, is she not a Woman? and is that Sex made for Privy Councellors? 'tis true, Chambermaids, I think take an oath of Secresie as they do; and might do well to keep it too, as some of the others do: but alas!—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Saving your mock-Morals and mongrel-Comments
On the whole Tribe, tell me of Beatrix, Sir,
What of her? what says she?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: What says she? why she says any thing; she can no more keep a secret than another woman, she is no more able to digest it; 'twill up Sir, 'twill up when occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Let Shift alone to mannage her Evidence,
He'l pump her drie, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Sure enough: for whether it be my Person, my nimble dapper Person; or my Wit, my fooling Wit she's taken with, or talking humour, in which we most Sympathize, I know not: but I'm sure, I taste more of her kindness then you do of her Mistresses:
However, our way of Love is nothing troublesome, tis free, and without any tye, we aim not at Hymen, we; as long as we like one another, so; when we are weary; so.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: A pretty modern Method.
sp.p: But prethee tell me Endiminion, art not thou sick of thy Constancy? hast not lov'd Clarinda long enough? to every fair one you were wont to cry, I love you; and scarce a whole day lov'd the same.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And yet Clarinda now with all her scorn
Has held him to't a Month;
'Tis a strange Metamorphose in your Worships humour.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I break custome, I confess it, for Clarinda's sake:
Yet let it not amaze thee, Bernard,
To see me burn so long in the same flames;
For if Love at first made me her Servant,
That Love is now to a Gaprichio vanisht,
A meer peevish obstinacie:
Her want of complaisance for my Amours
Is th' only reason why I haunt her now:
Not that I value her person, but I take
A pleasure in displeasing her; nor but
By vexing her can I wipe off the shame
This seeming Constancy would blast me with.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What a wrong sense I took you in all this while?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Why, you love her not then?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Not I, I thank my Starrs.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Why do you visit her then? why write? why send?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What in the name of Madness maketh you
That you are not in Love, play the fool, as those do that are?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Peevishness, I tell thee, meer peevishness;
Had she, when first I courted her,
With less severity welcom'd my Affection,
The fit had soon been over;
And in my way of making love, to another
E're this I had made offer of my heart;
But to knit one's brow, and look wise so out of season,
To fume and fret at every merry word,
And pay with frowns instead of smiles
A whole day together;
Then do I make love in despight.

sp.speaker: Bern
sp.l: Marry, y'are a terrible Lover indeed!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I see 'tis dangerous for a Woman to have to do with you; why? would you have 'em love you whether they can or no?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Is it so unpard'nable a Crime not to make much of you, that the punishment must never have end?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: But when will your Inconstance-ship get a new Mistriss, and think of this no more?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: As soon as thy dexterity has sifted out
VVho I am slighted for?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why, for Bellamy perhaps

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: For Bellamy?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Yes, for that very Bellamy
That has Courted her, you know, these Twelve Moneths
D'ee laugh?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That were a fine Match indeed!
Of all the gay men that frequent her
I ne'r was jealous of him yet.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why, he's a proper Gentleman, though but a poor one.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Clarinda is too proud to look so low
A mind like hers on state and bravery sett,
Is with a Fortune not a Person taken;
This Bellamy too has ever been her scorn.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What, if that were but a trick?
A meer dissembling trick, to cousen the old Man?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: They have more tricks then one then; for Bellamy
A week since left the Town;
Nay's shipt for France e'r this,
And yet you'd have 'em smitten still.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: There may be a trick in the Journey too, for—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Peace, yonder's Beatrix, feel her pulse a little,
Enquire, enquire how matters go; we'l step aside.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Tis enough, I have my kue.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Let's give him opportunity.—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What art thou thinking of now?
sp.stage: In a melancholly posture, his Cloak about his face.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Who I? I'm thinking of nothing.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What? in your dumps, when I come? when your Love comes?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: My Love? I have no Love, not I;
My Master loves no more, and I love no more neither.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: In earnest, Shift?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Yes in good earnest, Beatrix.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What, wilt thou forsake me now?
Thou canst not be so hard hearted sure?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: But I can, and will.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: This is but to try the constitution of my heart,
And peradventure to morrow.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Nay, there is no peradventure, nor no to morrow;
Is it not always like Master, like Man?
Make thy Mistriss love him, and then—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Thou must not request impossibilities at my hands,
Likely things I would do.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why? is Clarinda such a Love-hater?—
Is she so inflexible?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Not so much; but—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: But? but what?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: My poor Shift, thou hast so often promis'd me.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Let us come to the But; go on with your storie.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What should I tell thee?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why Clarinda uses Endimion with such base neglect?
And whether or no to love her still
Be operam & oleum perdere?
Thou maist smell my meaning, for Lamp-oyl has a strong sent.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I could tell thee all this and more; but—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: But what again?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I'm forbidden.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I'm glad o'that; she'l tell therefore.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Yet if thou wouldst swear not to tell again—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why I can be as silent as the silent woman;
I'le be a dumb shew; or the Chorus to't at least,
I'le tell but all I see: judge by my taciturn aspect.
I never tell but one thing at a time.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Thou wilt not tell then?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Not I; what I do not know.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: But swear to keep counsel.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: By my shifting faith, I will. Is not that well sworn?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Shifting faith? heyday! what faith's that?
This is an oath of a new fabrick sure,
What anvil came it off? prythee did'st thou forge it?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: The faith of Shift is a shifting faith:
But let not that stick with thee;
Men shift their faith now-a-days, as often
As they did their Trenchers, when this old Cap was new.
But to the point.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: You must know then that Clarinda, my Mistress—
But you must not tell your Master, Shift.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You would fain shift by your storie,
sp.p: But 'twill not be: let me have it then, and quickly; for now I observe you better, I find by your simpring, and by the fumbling of your apron (that's a main sign) that if I long to hear it, thou dost e'en twitter to tell; leave your halting then before as very a Cripple as your self, and come roundly to the business.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why, I must tell thee then—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: No Prefaces, nor Preambles.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: That if thy Master be unkindly dealt with,
The reason is Clarinda

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Has another Love.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Th'art e'en i'th right on▪ t.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Well, his name, his name? go on.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Must you know more yet?
Y'are very inquisitive into Women's matters.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I do not talk like a man-midwife? do I?
His name, I say, his name?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: That poor Cavalier?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: 'Tis a noble compleat Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And with his compleat Gentility
Thy Mistress will send thee to market? yes, she may;
But then must thou pawn thy coif and pinner,
Or come home without Eggs and Butter.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: She dot's on him, who can help it?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: All the dotage is on her side belike,
Hee'd nere leave her sure to go for France,
Did he dote too.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: That Journey on design is given out;
But to speak truth, should he fall into the free-booters hands
We were in some danger.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: He's safe then, and on this side the sea?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Yea, and in London too, as I may tell you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: In London?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: And nere was out on't.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Who the devil taught him to Romance so finely?
To delude all the town, but Clarinda,
And you their confiding Mopse,
He has taken as solemn a leave
As he had been going to Tangler, or to Tyburn.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: By this means he sees Clarinda every night, by her appointment too, and has done this week: and while his friends pity him, and think him sea-sick, he's Land-sick, and Love-sick, good Gentleman. There's but small hopes, thou see st, for thy Master.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: So me thinks.
But is not your Ladie afraid of the Lampon-makers?
Has she a mind to be in a Ballad?
There are some Women have had whole bundles made of'em
Upon less occasion, (as they say themselves.)
Hoard up smooth faces, keep 'em leiger in a garret all day
To play at bopeep by night.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Alas! thou art too severe, to young Ladies especially;
The nights the onely time for their recreation:
But we have a care of our ways,
And make a Conscience of being taken in 'em,
I'd have you know.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Just as the Lacedemonians did of pilfering.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why 'tis not a blot till it be hit, Man.
This night-work is so contriv'd.
That Bellamy steals into the garden by a back-door,
Which I leave open for him, and so to an arbour,
Where she waits his coming.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: An excellent Rendez-vous for a midsummer Moon,
But this hot weather won't last always.
Where shelters he all day?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: At Gratian'S, as close as he that fears an Execution,
And that's the reason too perhaps he gives his friend
Of this concealment, for he's not of the Councel,
Nor should I have been, I think;
Could they have carried businesses without me:
But I am right necessary Woman sometimes.
Fare thee well, give me thy hand;

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Farewel, farewel.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Thou dost promise me, Shift?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Promise thee? what?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Marriage, and't shall please thee.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Go thy ways, I do; when we are at age.
Is this the honour they vapour with?
This the reputation they are so shie of?
How many are there of this deceitful sex,
That wear Vertue enough all day,
And lay it by at night with their black patche;
And the rest of their superfluous ornaments?
Has Clarinda her Love-qualms too? well, the
Best of 'em have their failings, that I see.
But now am I as over-loaden with this secret;
Oh, how heavie it is? I shall shrink under the burthen
An I carrie it any further; I'm sure I'm sick on't alreadie.
O here's my Master, he'l cure me.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Hast thou found out the reason of my disgrace?
Is Clarinda engag'd else-where?
Is it pride, is it hate makes her so coy?
What other Gallants has she? why dost not speak?
Art deaf? or hast thou lost thy tongue?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Why standst thou making faces thus, and clutching thy fist?

sp.speaker: End
sp.l: Why doest thou squeeze thy fingers so? speak.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: O good Sir, let me alone.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Let thee alone? why what art doing?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You'l put me out now;

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Put thee out? of what? th' art out of thy wits already sure.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Now was I striving all this while to hold my peace;
I was bid; but the truth is, I am so farre
From doing as I was bid,
That I'm e'en weary of striving already: heark you then
That Spruce, Compleat out-sided Gallant, he that of all
Her gay frequenters nere gave you Jealous pang,
That very Bellamy, I told you of before,
That gives out he's gone for France,
By Clarinda's own contrivance is conceal'd at Gratian's.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Bellamy in town still?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: As sure as you are; and see's her every night.
Alas, he had no arrant into France,
But to make an ass of your Worship,
And that it seems he can do better at home.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: One of 'em shall dearly pay for't though.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why, what d'you mean to do?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, I'm resolv'd, I'le to Clarinda again.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Oh poor Beatrix, you'll tell Sir now,
And then is she undone for ever.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: No, no, ne'r fear it.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What good will it do you to see her then?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I mean to laugh at her, and for a full revenge
With deep protests will I renew my suit
If slighted, i'th same coin I'll pay her instantly,
And give her scorn for scorn;
A biting jeast or two, and I am even with her.
When she peceives my Vows were raileries,
Which meerly to divert my self I pass'd upon her,
'T will shrewdly pinch her, that I'm sure of,
For she that thinks she's fair indeed,
VVill ne'r endure to have been told so but in jest.
But prethee the whole story of this fine Amouretta,
Bellamy sees her every night, it seems.
I cannot wish 'em joy yet heartily,
There are some dregs of Love still lurking under my anger.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Lewis sir is here. End. 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You shall know more anon.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Go thou, and warily sift out
Of some Neighbour or so, if I may see Clarinda.
That is whether—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I understand, you are afraid of the old Man,
You would have him safe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: smiling. Th' art i' th' right
That's a stumbling block must be remov'd.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: May a friend be partaker of your Mirth?
Or know but whence it springs?
Clarinda without doubt
Has better thoughts of Love then she was wont,
'Tis not an unbecomming weakness now, I hope,
Y' have wrought a cure upon her, I see it in your looks.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nothing less; she never was more avers'd, nor I
More lost to all hopes of ever being favour'd by her.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: In what tearms then must one condole your loss?
Or with what Arguments.—

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Nay, never set your Rhetorick o' th' Tenterhooks for the matter,
Not quicken your invention with your nails,
He can live without her.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I praise my manly temper.
The loss Lewis I do not much regret;
And wert thou fit for such a secret now—

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: You do me wrong to doubt my keeping it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I would acquaint thee with my whole Adventure:
I have discover'd how the Market goes,
And see why I am not thought to bid fair,
The scorns Clarinda heapt on me
Were favours she oblig'd a Rival with;
She's in love man, desperately in love
See how the World's mistaken in her,
And how groundless my pretensions are.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: Clarinda in love? vers'd with that subtilty too
In his dissembling Maxims to carry it thus?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis a wonder; she that stood upon her guard
And kept us at such distance, to be taken?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: She that set Love and Lovers at defiance,
And seem'd so scrupulously modest, that to name
I ut Venus to her or Cupid, was talking bawdy.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But who's the luckie Woodman has struck this fair Doe?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That's the wonder of all wonders, Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Away, away, now I see you jest.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: It is a serious and a sober Truth, sir,
A sad one too it might prove for some body,
Had not I more discretion then all Lovers have.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: The French journey's but a fiction, Man,
A meer slight to make their meetings
Private and unsuspected.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But see what a goodly choice she has made,
What a happiness she refuses me for;
A Man of no Fortune, Estate I mean,
For luck he has enough to fool me;
If 'twere wit he out-did me at,
He'd do't above board, and by day-light.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Y'are misinform'd, I'm sure on't;
I know Clarinda better then so, besides Bellamy
For another Beauty burns, though't flame not out.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: For who?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: For Celia.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Have you acquaintance with her?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Not much; this I know, she's a great Gallant,
Lives in the Fields here, with a Widow-Aunt
And is Courted by him; 'tis true, Gratitude
As much perhaps as Love, may draw that Courtship
For his engagements to the Lady are great,
His bosome friend has told me all,
One that were happy could your surmize prove true.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I go upon sure grounds, Beatrix is my Author,
And not to tell you a secret by the halfes
He keeps close at a friends house of yours all day,
At Gratian's-

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: See where he comes; give me leave, and Ile know all;
He'l make no secret of't to me, I'm confident,
Nor will I to you of what I learn from him.
What pensive still?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: And miserable still.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What new misfortune causes this complaint?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: 'Tis an old grief mine, Lewis; how often
Have I told you with what passion
I burn for Celia, and with what violence
Done to my self I do forbear all words
That might disclose that passion a friend
Is Rival in? judge of my miserie then,
For sure no torments equallize his pain,
That dyes for love, yet dares not once complain.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: How out of season these respects are now?
When Bellamy's absence gives you place;
Take th' opportunity,

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I'm ne're the happier for a Rivals absence.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: No? that's strange; but I hear, let me tell you,
His French Journey's laid aside, nay, was ne're intended.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Who tells you so?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Nay more, 'tis whisper'd he lies private at your house,
Nere seem amaz'd, but deal ingenuously.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I did not think it had been known abroad.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Not is it generally; but what is his design?
Or what can he aim at by this stealth?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I never div'd so farr into his breast:
I onely understood it did concern his life,
Or what was dearer then his life, his Love,
To disappear some time:
All I can guess besides, (and that
But by some words he does drop forth by chance)
Is, that some jealous thoughts disturb his mind,
And that to trie his Celia's real kindness,
He spreads this fain'd report of travel,
That as his absence proves to this fair one
Irksom or indifferent,
He may see the power of Rivalling Pretensions.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis hotly rumour'd though he loves Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: That's the town-trick:
Because he's young and courtly, Clarinda handsom,
He cannot visit her, but straight
He's thought in love; nay, though she be not
Beyond common Civility regarded by him,
Yet People need's will have him her Adorer.
The news with Celia too has wrought so farre,
'thas cost her tears; but he in such persuasive terms
Still vindicates his constancie,
She cannot long believe him false.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Is she so much his then still?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Too faithful to him ever, too fond indeed:
Though without taking leave he stole away,
She seeks her self pretences to excuse him,
And with such care does palliate his neglects,
As stops my mouth, and frustrates all my hopes.
While I (and that's my height of miserie)
To make him happy, court my own ruine,
Visit her at his request, wooe her for him,
And improve each minute to discourse his Love,
Fanning their heats thus, and childishly
Playing in a flame that must consume me.
She, with the very name of Bellamy ravisht,
To sit and chat of him intreats my visits:
I must comply.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis something a severe compliance.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Thus keep I still some interest in the family,
And have access to her; and if by some
Capriciousness of fate, which oft breaks kindest leagues,
They chance to jarre, she may perhaps reflect
A faithful friend seldom proves faithless Lover.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I wish it may be so.
But you'ld be visiting this cruel fair one.
May she with justice ballance both your services,
And then yours will be crown'd.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: See where she comes the fair Cause of all my grief;
No more then let the fear of displeasing her keep it in,
For though I should fall under her disdain,
Her beauty is concern'd I make it known
Her eyes have captiv'd her more slaves then one:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How happily do I meet you?
Sure Bellamy is landed long ere this?
A letter from Callis now me thinks, to make his peace.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Madam, I expect some by the French post.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Why writ he not from Dover? nay,
From Canterbury, from Rochester, from Graves-end?
Are they not all post-towns?
Oh! I could have found twenty ways to send to him.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: How well my Cozen knows the road?
Yet I dare swear she ne're was further
That way, then Southwark-fair.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Oh this Love is a subtle teacher, Mris Fannie.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Has it taught you any thing, Luce?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nay, I have reason to be angry with him,
To steal away thus, and never bid adieu.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Thence you may judge how great his passion is,
That fatal word, Adieu, had he but spoke it,
Must have been his last; of so much beauty,
So much kindness too, who without dying
Could have taken leave?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'm easily won, Gratian,
To a favourable construction of all he does;
My love indeed pleads for him still: and yet
What ere the reason of his absence be,
I might, me thinks, have been acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Nay, Madam, I excuse him not, he is too guilty;
I know what courtesies he is indebted to you,
With what a liberal hand you ever pour'd them on him,
And that when—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No more of that, I pray;
A Courtesie looses its merit if publisht once;
Would I be minded oft, I did deserve
He should forget it. Besides if I may
Freely own the motive of those actions
I pleasur'd my self most in obliging him,
I did but justice to his fair desert:
And yet I'le not acquit him neither, I'le think
As you would have me more deservingly
Of what I did; there's no gift though he's bound
To me for, saving that of my heart, my
Love I'ld have requited, then all is paid.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: That is the gift too he does value most:
And that he might not all Ungrateful seem
To the fair giver, when a necessity
Sudden as unwelcome forc'd him from what he lov'd,
He sought to leave you one half of himself
Gratian, to fill his room.
And friendship now making but one of us,
If 'mong your discontents you reckon his absence,
It shall be my care to supply his place;
With tears and sighs I'le figure you his grief,
And will (to act your Bellamy to th' life,)
Forget I am not he; from the same Eyes
I'le draw my warmth, with the same passions burn,
And in this personated Love outvie—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Enough, enough: for I begin to fear
Least the pretence of speaking for another
Should urge you further then a friends interest
Usually does, friendship transports you, Gratian;
Temper its heat a little.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: A forward Proxie! hee'ld wed, and bed her
For his friend, would she but let him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But shee's not so comming; though he
Would fain take himself for Bellamy,
She'll not mistake him so too.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: My silence argued me remiss and slack,
And venture at a word, I'm beaten back.

div.head: ACT. II.
The SCENE, Lincolns-Inn-fields.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: BY my modesty, Madam, I'le keep your Counsel: Alas
I stand in need of the like good office my self sometimes,
And they that tell deserve to be told of, I say.
Yet could I but understand what you drive at
I might be more serviceable.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What account can I give thee?
In such perplexitie my mind's involv'd,
I know not what I would my self.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: You love Bellamy though,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh Wench I do.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: And that's it puzzles me now, to see so high an affection
Mushrom-like sprung up o'th sudden, Bellamy
Has courted you, and recourted you sigh'd & sob'd, again & again,
Yet all would not do, you were as coy still and as calm,
As nothing had been; nothing but frumps
Could he get of you in a whole years time,
Nothing but No's, and I wo' not's, and I cannot's,
And now in one week y'are so strangely alter'd,
As you were turn'd the wrongside outward;
Y'are got into the loving extream now.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Alas! I lov'd him all that while;
Though knowing how much a Wealthy fathers bent
Against Pretenders of so small a fortune,
Set cold neglect and rigour in my eyes,
While my heart e'en melted with hot love.
This seeming cruelty had driven him into France,
Could I have worn it still, but thou saw'st me
Beaten from that ward; and yield, though he
Gave out he went, he should not go indeed.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Truly y'are to be pitied: but what good
Can this counterfeiting of a Journey do you?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: His intentions for travel were too well known abroad,
To have the Journey broken thus o'th sudden;
And sifting out the cause, perhaps
Something o'th' truth of it might have been found.
'Tis safer to keep close by day awhile,
And then pretend some reason for's return.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Endimion, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: His importunity will nere have end.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Is it not just I quarrel with my Starrs
That I can never see you? will you keep home always?
Must none enjoy you, but your self?
I shall grow jealous of yourself at last.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Home is most pleasing to me, and retired thus
I see but what I like, and will my self;
What moves you to press on my retirement?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Will you never take pity of my sufferings?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Bewail your self some where else, I'm ignorant of your griefs.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Love.— Clar. Never name a Tyrant I abhor.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But a Lover that suffers.—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Leave out that name of Lover,
There is such a discord in the sound, I hate it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Unjustly though, methinks;
For sure with fewer charms Nature does frame
What she means not the object of our Loves.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Will you never leave this odious talk?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Will you be lovely thus, and cruel still?
Oh what Flames do those Eyes kindle in my breast!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What aversion does this discourse beget in mine!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Heavens! how they sparkle? how many deaths
They shoot, those Star-like twins?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh, I could hate the Sun, whose light I see you by.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: The Moon indeed is something kinder to you,
No doubt, but to her light
You are beholding for a lovelier sight.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You will not.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You think to fright me with this obscure discourse.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I can clear it, if I am put to't.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis time to be gone then;
I see y'are angry, and might use me worse,

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: staying her Without hearing my reasons?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I care not for 'em:

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But you must hear 'em though; 'tis a Love-suit
I am concern'd in, you shall be judge i' th' case;
Y'have heard my Adversary at leisure,
And tane perhaps some prejudice against my right;
'Tis my turn now to have an Audience of you,
Since he has it by night, I may well
Claim one by day; not that I do expect
A Garden door should be left jarr'd
For me to slip in, nor Beatrix there
Confidingly to watch, none interrupt my story;
Much less that you your self should wait
My comming in an Arbour.
Were I suppos'd in France, and yet in spight of Seas
Could meet you at an hours warning, then indeed
I might deserve a kindly welcome.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A pox on's memory! he has not left out a tittle,
What a speech has he made here?
Could I find no body else to tattle too?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What have I heard?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Oh Sir! what have you done?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: 'Tis but a just revenge of her unjust
And undeserved scorn.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: to Be. Thou hast betrayed me,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Believe me, Madam.—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Away thou faithless wretch, thou hast sold me;
Unhappy she, that trusts such mercenary souls.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: to End. Now will poor Beatrix be turn'd away.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I would to Heaven you did not with your anger
Avow your self what I had still conceal'd,
And this reproaching me did not confirm.—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Peace Impudence: justifying yourself?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: to End. I had need of a good back now,
'Twill all fall upon me.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: 'Tis past now, who can help it? but for my interest,
For thine own, for Beatrix sake, for all; prethee Shift
And thou canst, peece it up again; make any shift.
Invent, Frame, Lye, Swear, anything, I'le second it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis resolv'd, ne'r speak on't more:

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Well, I must pack then, since you'l have it so
But may I now before your face, if ever I told tale.—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh, 'tis an innocent piece!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I have much adoe sir, to make a good lie o'th' sudden;
But this shall serve for want of a better.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Good or bad, let's have it; I'le help thee out.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And you turn me away to morrow sir, I will tell
I'le speak the Truth in spight of all Masters, I:

sp.speaker: To Clar.
sp.l: Madam, put up your anger, or turn it the right way:

sp.speaker: To End.
sp.l: Nay, never wink on me, nor frown,
Nor make me signs to hold my peace;
Truth must be heard, and shall.

sp.speaker: To Clar.
sp.l: Beatrix never betray'd your secrets,
Nor does she prattle of your Love,
The Stars, the Stars themselves discover'd all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What means the Fellow?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You don't believe me now?
But I must tell you though, and you'l find it true too,
That this Master of mine (as out of countenance as you see him)
Has not stowage for his great Capacity,
Nor the World his fellow in Astrology,
The Man i' th' Strand was an Ass to him, when he was at best,
He can make the Brazen head speak at this hour,
Spirits he could raise Sans nombre
And make them talk too,
Till we were all weary of their company.
If ever an Endimion slept in the Moon's lap,
This is he, for he has as much familiarity with her,
To my knowledge, as that comes to.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Thy Master an Astrologer?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I, Twenty.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What Twenty Astrologers, and but one Man?
Thou wilt tell a lie anon.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I mean, he casts Figures, and raises Appearances
As fast as Twenty;

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: This story'll cry me up for a fine fellow.

sp.speaker: To Sh.
sp.l: What sirrah? Sh. Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: If she would but believe him now!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Nay, you are an Astrologer if ever man was:
I know I loose my place, and forfeit my no small
Arrears of wages too in discovering it,
But I love Beatrix, Queen of Beatrixes.
And ought to free her from the suspicion

sp.speaker: To Clar.
sp.l: Her Mistress has conceiv'd; he has made me mad
This week with his Ovals and his Circles,
He contemplates the Stars in nights so dark
They dare not appear, and is staring abroad,
When the dogs will not peep out.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Well said, Bull-dog!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: By Moon-light, by Owl-light, by any light,
By no light; and in his Chamber
Continually poaring on a great black Book
Full of pot-hooks of all sorts and sizes,
The Inventory o' th' Devils Kitchin, 'tis I think:
And thus has he discover'd your Amours
But in what Devils name, or which leaf of the Book
Y'are written in, truly that I cannot tell you yet.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: This is a jesting Knave, and yet
There may be some Truth in what he says too;
Stranger things have been found out by that Art.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Why, thou everlasting prittle prattle!
will't never have done? who has hired thee here
To tell a story of a Cock and a Bull?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I▪ I, Cocks and Bulls; those are some of your Familiars.
Madam, I have not said a word, but what is true.
I'le justify't, let him raise as many devils as he will,
What I have said will shame 'em all.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Meaning, 'tis truth he has spoke;
Which is not the least of his lies.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Did not you shew me a Garden.
Last night, in one of your enchanted Glasses,
And bid me mark an Arbour to the West of that Garden?
I know not West from East, not I;
But I perceiv'd it stood in one corner of the Garden,
And mark'd it so well, I can tell you
What 'twas made of too, of Lauretine.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: There is such an Arbor i'th' Garden.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Yes Madam, there is indeed:
God-a-mercy though, that he saw it once,
When I took him into th' Garden,
His Master's glasses had nere shew'd it him else.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: But that you chiefly bade me observe,
And were your self so vext at heart to see,
Was the Lady Clarinda here sitting in that arbour;
In a melancholy posture you were, I'le assure you, Madam,
Thus with your hand supporting of your head,
And look'd, in my eye, as you had waited
For something, made you think the time long ere it came;
And so it prov'd indeed; for casting by command my eye
To another side of the Mirrour, I spied a Gallant
Enter'd the Garden make straight up to the arbour,
And saw your first salute; 'tis true, I could not
Hear him what he said, (and by that I guess
The devil's not so great with th' ears as with the eyes.)
But I suppose he did excuse his coming late,
And took such special notice of his garbe,
I'd know him in a croud of Courtiers,
Amongst clowns any one might discern him,
I could describe his habit too for need—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Oh! you have said enough, Sir, you have said enough;
And more then will stand with my credit, Madam,
To have believ'd, I'm worse then an Astrologer then,
He makes me conjure too: but since it is not
For my honour now to hide the truth from you;
I must confess that in my travels
'Twas my fortune to grow intimate with a learned Man,
Sometime a Scholar to the fam'd Nostredamus,
Who took some pains with me, my aptness
To his impressions making him with pleasure, as he said,
Impart his secrets, nor knew he ought
In Physiognomy, Palmistry, Astronomy,
Nor hardly in all the Mathematicks
He read not to me; what ere belongs, I'm sure,
To th' Opticks or Mechanicks he did disclose.
Thus came my skill.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I never heard this so perfectly before.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I don't think thou didst.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But to own it publickly
I know too well the disrepute 'tis in
Amongst the Vulgar, too apt to give events
(Whose cause their dull capacity cannot reach)
To the black Art, and think the devil author
Of all subtleties above 'em; which makes my man
Talk of familiars, and take (dull brain!)
Our Optick glasses for enchanted one's.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Besides the wrong some late Professors too
Have done that art, by prostituting it
To men in power.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: A servile flatterie!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Made him more cautious in such times as those,
When it was dangerous not to be base,
How he seem'd knowing.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But tired out at last with
Your too rigorous usage, your servants all
Too trusty, or too ignorant to betray me
The cause on't;
I was resolv'd to find it out my self
In that great book, where truth's so fairly writ
For those have studied the bright Character:
I did consult the stars,
I found the garden, and the arbour too,
Bellamy's real happiness, and suppos'd absence.
But let not this discovery trouble you,
For my own interest I must keep your Counsel,
Our fortune is the same, 'tis but one secret for another,
My Man has told you mine, I found out yours,
Keep you but one of 'em, and I warrant you for the other.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: 'Tis an able Man, I promise you!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You'l believe me another time, I hope,
I was i'th right, you see.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: The truth, I trow, does justifie me now, Madam.
I had heard it mutter'd indeed, he took upon him
To tell fortunes, interpret dreams, or so;
And could have made Almanacks too, for his skill,
But that he thought it a discredit to his youth,
To grow weather-wise so soon: but I had sold you,
I had betrayed you, I; he knew all from me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Truth, I was loath to suspect thee,
I had no former grounds for't;
Had it not been for his Astrologie though,
What could he have known, unless I had been betray'd.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: You may, remember too, if any Incredulity remain,
How much my old Master talks of Astrologie,
And what feats he was wont to do in's youth,
As he tells us, by the Vertue of Mars and Venus.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My father talks much of Astrologie indeed,
What I have heard from him, helps to perswade,

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Thou could'st not pitch upon a quainter fancie.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Twas extempore, Sir, remember that,
And may give some small hint of my faculty;
A little premeditation had afforded you a better.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: It needs not, this fable is as currant with her.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Nay, she is finely fool'd; you shall
Have her in such a suppliant Style now,
She's sore afraid of you, I see by her eyes.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Noble Endymion, whose clear-sighted mind
Is onely paralel to your generous heart.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Did I not tell you?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Hear her Apologie.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: A slighted Lover's anger I should fear,
Were the excuse I am now to make you,
Due to any other, but you that know
The Influence of the stars, and force of destiny,
Will not deem it a Crime in me, to act
What they decree: when great ones can't eschew
What they portend her, what should weak women do?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Peace, peace, your father's coming,
Your father's coming; 'tis his hem.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Would he would hem some where else,
We did not want him here.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Now, what's the business with this young Gallant?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis Curiosity, Sir, I must confess;
I heard not long since by a friend of mine,
He was most knowing in Astrologie,
And having by her means wrought his acquaintance,
A Maiden-longing, which I blush to own,
Made me now question him 'bout my husband's name,
And when I should be married.
I'le try your skill though for once good Mr Astrologer.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: The old man wil have him into the Star-chamber presently.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: She doubts my science, & sets him on to make trial of't to Sh.
I le bear up bravely, and 't shall go hard,
But I'le beat that old tired Cock out o'th' pit.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Are you a fortune-teller? do'e make Almanacks? hah!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Montelions perhaps, or so.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: He's the sprucest truly o'th trade, I ere yet saw.

div.stage: They stand aside with Shift, who tells them what has past between his Master and Clarinda.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: How rudely the man begins? this is no fair disputant.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: What does he tell thee troubles thee thus?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I told her, Sir, of some hard fortune, which
By th' malign aspect of an inauspicious Planet
I find her threatned with.
She takes it somewhat to heart, as you see.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Thou art too blame, thou art too blame
To be so much concern'd.
In so short a time what could you discover?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That shee's decree'd
To make the fortunes of a younger Brother,
Or some such wanting Gentleman;
For he whom she's to marrie
Is rich in person onely, and a comely mine.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Who would not think he spoke truth now,
He delivers himself with such confidence?
The good Gentleman out-lies his man,
Foils him at his own weapon, Impudence.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Fear it not upon such slight grounds,
'Tis but one Doctors, opinion, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I would I had not heard it though;
The Prediction has made strong impressions on me.
Would it did so on you too, that you might be perswaded
There were no remedy, but I must have Bellamy,
The fine wanting Gentleman he points at.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr
sp.l: My Daughter meat for younger Brothers?
Fear 'em not I say again, let me alone
To stave them off, and wanting Heirs are as bad to me
As a poor Cadet, I'le beware of them too.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Endimion, though that reads my destiny thus,
Is a knowing Man, Father, one never yet mistaken,
Nor ever saw he, as he protests
The Stars on any one Event six'd so unanimous;
This would work, I think, on any one,
It falling so right with my own desires.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: She takes more pains to delude her Father,
Then I did to gull her: I shall be an Astrologer
At this rate, whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Many Men have employ'd all their Lives
In this Study, and yet died short
O' th' excellence of it too; and how this Man
Should arrive at the height of it so young,
I wonder much, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: It is with Schollars, I have heard, Sir,
As with Travellers; not always he that first sets forth,
But he that takes the nearest way, gets soonest home.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: And what of him that's best hors'd?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: He out-rides his fellows.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Why, thou art a parcel wise Man too.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Certes Astrologie is a noble Science,
Worth th' application of ingenious minds!
If you are such a Master of her secrets,
Few that pretend to th' name come near
Deserving it so well; all men
Are not fit for speculation now a-dayes,
Youth especially, is all on Action bent;
So young therefore, and so learned, deserves
All Honour and Applause; and I am heartily yours.
I ever was affected to Men of merit,
A lover of Learning always, I:
And to speak truth, in my younger days
I was a dabler this way too, my self;
But marrying too soon, marr'd my Study,
My Wife burnt all my Books, and I soon fell
From casting Figures, to cast up accounts;
Domestick care, Law-suits,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: And good-fellowship too a little.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Kept me from excelling▪ but tell me Sir, I pray;
Are not those Planets (Mars and Saturn excepted)
Of the happiest influence, whose Paralels are the greatest?
How like you Mercury beholding Venus,
With a trine Aspect? or, what think you,
Of the same Mercury in conjunction with Hecate?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: The Man speaks Hebrew sure;
And he would take his answer in Gibberish now,
'Twere some thing:

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Here are words as able to fright away an Ague,
As Voiture's Abracadabra

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: He had need be an Astrologer now indeed

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I'le have one push for't.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Heark, he has provided an answer

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: to Sr Chr. Those Planets I account the happiest, none excepted,
Whose influence on Man and Woman pour down
What each desireth most.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Learnedly answered!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Venus, you know your self, (but that y'are pleas'd
To try my younger skill;) to Lovers does presage all bliss,
As Mars has a kindness for the Men of War;
Saturn is powerful with the Saturnians:
Marry, if Mercury eye Venus once,
There are Cuckolds made i'th' City:
Some false Dice▪ may be abroad too,
For he was a wag both ways, you know.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: But what if with a trine Aspect, what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That's worst of all, Sir; then are the Cuckold-makers at work
In City, Court, and Countrey: if with a trine Aspect,
Then let all Men look to their Wives,
Their handsome Wives especially.
Oh, 'tis a Cornuting Constellation!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And governs this Cornuting age.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I never heard why we had so many Cuckolds before.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed, law-Daughter, I would
He had told thee thou should'st have
A rich old Knight, or some Alderman;
For sure enough he had reason for what he said,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: No question but he had, though neither she,
Nor you, know what reason

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: But what of the Conjunction, Sir,

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Of Mercury with Hecate?
I have much adoe to speak the Goblin-words after him,
It is a very critical one.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Is it so? is it so? indeed?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Have at him now with down right non-sence.
To Sr Chr. The Triplicity of it, as well as the Union
Of Hecate with Mercury, being Retrograde,
Or in combin'd Aspects, in the Horizon
Of a cross Ascendant, on such weak brains
Might paralax at last.—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Y'are too high for me, I promise you;
This is all out of my reach; if you would descend
To somewhat a more vulgar and intelligible phrase.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: These are terms of Art, Sir.
I thought I should pose you.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Pardon my age, Sir; 'tis so long since I
Broak Correspondence with the Art, the tearms
Are as strange to me now, as I ne'r had heard 'em;
And methinks too, they hardly were in use
When I was at the University:
But time that alters us, will alter Science too,
It has a daily increase, though we decay,
And other Countreys may have other Methods.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Of late years, Sir, in the Mathematicks
There are great alterations, they erect Schemes
A new way now, and have new names
Belonging to the Horoscope, Nostradamus him self,
Whom my Master follow'd, had his tearms
And rules apart, wherefore the phrase
I'm studied in, may well seem strange to you.
But School-men are like Carriers-horses; We plod on
In our old pad; like us, or understand us, who will.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Do you so? do you so? That's something strange methinks,
Yet amongst friends, you might vouchsafe, Sir, to be understood.

sp.speaker: La-gripe.
sp.l: To Sr Chr. A vord vis your Vorship.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: How now? what's the matter, Lagripe?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You claw it away with hard words.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Thou seest, I sweat for't;
But for a friend now at need, relieve me
With an errand, or find some trick or other
To take off this old Lover, of he knows not what

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Your Pardon, Sir, it is an earnest business,
I should not leave you else, I'm e'en full loath as, 'tis,
For I did long to understand those new tearms,
That I did: but we shall meet again
And discourse these learned Misteries, we'l try
Some Mathematical experiments too;
Nay, I have some Secrets worth your knowing:
But farewel farewel for this time.

div.stage: Ex. Sir Chr. Clar. Beat. Lagripe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I had rather believe you, then stand to sift 'em out.
I'm rid of him without thy help at last.
Lewis, Bernard, I have had the finest adventure,
The prettiest part put upon me.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Shift has made us laugh at it alreadie,

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: We stood aloof off all the while, and heard
How astrologically the old man question'd you:

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: And as Astrologically I answer'd him, I hope:
But he could not follow through the houses of the Sun
The pace I led him, he lost sight of me presently.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: You did not vanquish him fairly, he understood you not.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: It had been much he should,
When I did not understand my self.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis fit you take some pains in both,
He'l expect an expounding visit.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Bless me from undesign'd Encounters,
Such as this day's; and if by my good will
I visit him, let him plague me with non-sense;
Let him retaliate, and spare not.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: D'ee mean to trade in non-sense still?
A great Astronomer, or one taken for such—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Hee'l quickly find how I played upon him,
For what questions did he put to a Man,
That knows neither Signs nor Planets?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: With your bold answers you so mall'd him though,
He's yet well stunnied, and with as much ease
I durst wager, you'l foil him next encounter.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Give him t'other fall, compleat your Victorie,
'Tis for the credit of learning
The work be not left imperfect.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: We'l be the trumpet of your fame,
And sound your skill throughout the town.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: What think you of posting up bills?
As others of the profession do.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And give some at the Play-house doors
As they do for a match at the Bear-garden.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Or get him put into the Gazette
By way of Advertisement for the publick good
Of what a Mine of Learning is discover'd.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Either will convince the old knight,
And if besides, by strangers we shall have prepar'd,
Th' amazing rumour of your daily wonders
But reach his ear, as I'le be sure it shall;
Being full already of this first enterview,
He'l be so gull'd, as nere old dotard was.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That I believe; but this fine pastime
Venture's me a little too farre;
You consider not the danger may ensue,
Engaging thus my credit, and my quiet too; for 'twill
Draw all the curious fools o'th' town about my ears.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: So we shall know how full the town is of fools,
And should they find, y'are but a counterfeit,
'Twill pass but for a trick of youth at worst.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What sport soever we may fancie thus,
It cannot last long; for if it be
So generally bruited, I shall have questi ns
Put me hourly, and then my answers.
Must doubtless get me great repute.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: What matter? you'l answer as other Pretenders do,
Sometimes I, sometimes no; be it favourably,
Or fatally; have some respect to age and sex,
And for the rest, happy be lucky.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A fortune-teller never warrants any thing;
You answer not upon oath, Sir; and then you know,
One may strain a little, without venturing ears.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: In Astrologie the best of 'em does as much
By chance as skill: 'tis meer hab-nab.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What if you throw Cross or Pile, whether you say,
I, or no. or tell your buttons, I, no; I, no:

sp.speaker: End
sp.l: There are ways indeed.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why, 'tis an even lay, you hit right either way,
When there is but a right and a wrong in the case.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Have I not read of a judge was swayed by
Cast of Dice in trials of Life and death?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: The high fulloms sav'd some, the low hang'd the rest.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: This remember; never to affirm any thing
With certainty, with what is past or present
Be very cautious how you meddle,
'Tis as dangerous in this Profession
As speaking treason; o'th' future it self
Speak but obscurely neither, to your Consulters
'Twill pass for learnedly, they must
Allow you to be i'th' clouds a little.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Let your Answers be like Oracles, wonder'd at,
Not understood, foretel more good fortune
For the most part then bad,
That will send 'em away pleas'd at least:

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And in that good humour they'l remember
Your poor servants; our Wages may be earn'd this way.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Thou Mercenary fool.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Here's Gratian; be gone,
Wee'l begin with him, he's credulous.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I leave it t'ee, Gentlemen;
Manage the device as you will your selves,
Come Shift.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Who would have thought it?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Who can well believe it yet?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis strange.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: 'Tis beyond imagination.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: How is it with you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: We hardly know our selves;
We are wrapt in such a cloud of Wonders;

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Most miraculous!

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: May not I know what? I would fain wonder too.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I fear least—

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: You need not; here's none to over-hear us.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But it requires a secrecy.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Trust me.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Endimion declar'd even now,

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Declar'd? what?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: And did before our face things so incredible
Almost to eye-witnesses, I'm loth to speak 'em.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: What did he do?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I never met with, nor indeed heard of his fellow.
He is so highly knowing in Astrologie,
And shews his skill in practises so admirable,
I could suspect he conjur'd.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: He told me passages of my life, and almost in an instant,
Which without Enchantment, I know not
How he should discover: yet all he did,
Was by Conjectures from my palm and face,
And certain figures drawn o'th' sudden;
For he is also a Chiromancer, and a Physiognomist.
Who could imagine, seeing him so spruce, so gay?—

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Is it not Endimion the Wit, that travell'd Monsieur,
Whose Gallantry and Conversation are so much cried up:
He's of the Society too, I think.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Yes, yes, an eminent member: he has some rare secret sure
Which other Artists are not yet arriv'd at.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I ever took him for a well-willer
To the Mathematicks indeed; Some twice or thrice,
I think, I have convers'd with him,
And found him then, both by his Countenance and discours
An Astrologer, I will not say,
For that great knowledge he took care, belike,
To hide from all, but bosome friends;
But a person of sharp wit and excellent understanding
I clearly saw he was;
A Man addicted too to curious sciences.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What will you say, if I carry you with me
Some day, that he has undertaken
To shew me a Beautie, had some kindness for me
In Paris? the French Mistress y'have heard me speak of.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Is't possible he can?—

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: That's nothing to what he can do.
He made a Picture speak before us,
And that's the Cause of this astonishment.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: May I believe this?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: You have both Eyes an Ears, will you believe them?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Dear Lewis, make me better acquainted
With this rare Man; he▪ l tell me
Whether Bellamy be jealous, or no; and why.—

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I have enquir'd that out for you already:
He meets Clarinda by night, and abuses Celia.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: He does go out by night indeed

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: And to that purpose; never doubt it.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I'm overjoy'd, if it be so.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But not a word, dear Gratian, as you love me,
Of Endimion; he would be Lamm'd
If what we know were spread abroad.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Here's one i'th snare already.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Endymion an Astronomer, and Bellamy faithless!
Love give thee thanks, th' opportunity's a fair one;
I le straight to Celia, there I'le boast his Art,
By which, (if Love and I can make her bold enough)
She may discover how she is abus'd.
Then dispossest
Of the fair thoughts she holds of this false Man,
Her heart for me becomes an easie prize.
Nor can he tax me with a breach of trust
That to his Mistriss is much more unjust,

div.head: The First SCENE, Endimion 's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter Endimion, Lewis, Bernard, Rawman, Shift with a Satchel at his back.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: FAmous Astronomer, most admired Genius,
You that are now the only Town-talk grown,
As never plot was half so well contriv'd,
So never any yet took as this does▪

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: No Man, but is perswaded of your skill,
No Man, but with respect does gaze upon you;
And it some cross accident spoil not the sport,
You will be taken for a Prophet shortly.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: And to preserve that good opinion, Sir,
See, I loose no time.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Witness my burthen here.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Why, what hast thou got there?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: His Worships Library.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I think I may be worthy to carry
Books after him, as famous a Man as he is.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: A Lillie's Almanack.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: And a Whartons.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: There's the Pro and Con
That will make him a good Disputant.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Wings Ephemerides! I marry Sir,
Here's an Airy Author indeed.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: My Master soars as high as the loftiest of 'em.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: You know the houses of the Sun, I hope, by this.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: As well as any man here does Coffee-houses or Bawdy-houses.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Peace Scurrility; that he had houses I knew before:

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I ever held him a mighty Prince,
And did believe he was well lodg'd.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p:
But now I know his Risings and his Settings too, Heliack,
Cosmick, and Acronick; the number of the Spheres, both Tropicks, that of Cancer, and of Capricorn, the Artick and Antartick-Poles, the Paralels, Ecliptick-line, the Climate, Point-Vertical: and what not.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Nay then, I'le lay aside this superfluous Learning,
He has enough without book.

div.stage: Carrys in the Satchel and returns.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Alas Sir, Mercury in conjunction with Hecate.
Or beholding Venus with a trine Aspect,
Thanks to my Almanack here, is not Hebtew now,
'Tis but a labour, though of memorie yet,
My Judgement is not much improv'd,
And I must shun Sir Christopher a while;
But what progress have you made with the Pageant?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: A fair one, I think, for the time,

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Such as you'ld laugh to trace us thorow.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: My first station was to a house where I
Was sure I should meet company, and of
The best; a kind of Lady-ordinary,
Where they were beasting it, for that game's in
Fashion still, though Hombre be more Courtly.
To th' standers by, I whisper'd first my news,
Then 'mongst the Bettors it began to spread,
At last it wrought the Gamesters too, and found
Even amongst the loosers such concern,
They could sit still, and question me about you;
They must play on though, but they were so full
of Signs and Planets, that in stead of Play
A Madam cried out Venus, and a Man
Of War for Counter, straight cried Mars.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I fear 'twas I beasted her.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: When I saw t work so well, I left 'em, and to th' play;
Where to disseminate my story best,
I'th' pit, I whisper'd it from ear to ear;
And thus confidingly it spread so well,
That by the end it was in every mouth:
Going out, (I laugh still at the conceit)
A friend rounds me i'th ear with my own lye,
Which with so many oaths he vouch'd for truth,
I made some scruple not to believe him.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: A most excellent progress!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Is it not?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But prethee Bernard, where hast thou preacht me up?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: To Court, I; for that's the staple of news.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I'le see what they say of my Master at the Bake-house,
For that's my staple of news.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: But peeping by the way into th' Exchange,
I met with one did lye for you the heartiliest,
Relating twenty monstrous things y' had done,
To which he swore himself a witness too:
Some five or six had hemm'd him in,
And hung upon his tongue, his lying tongue,
With an attention great as his impudence;
I hearkened too a while, (then to try his mettle)
Took on me to contest some points he had averr'd:
But he, full fraught with wrath and indignation;
I speak but what I' ve seen, and you perhaps
Gain-say't for want of knowledge of the person,
Or else you envie men of worth and parts.
When I, seeing him so fierce, for fear of being beaten,
E'en sneak'd away to laugh at him at leisure.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What impudent fellows there are about this Town?
Travellers and Falk oners are modest to this vap'ring, Sir,
'Twere an excellent Genius to write Diurnals;
Is he not something a kin to old Politicus, think you?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: He would out-lye him some furlongs

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Novelty has its Sectators every where
As gross lies pass for currant truth daily.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: They did indeed.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But why baulk'd you Grays-Inn-walks, the Coffee- (houses or some sage Club.
There your grand News-mongers conferre.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Retailers of grave, serious lies, they:
But mine was for the young, the gamesome ones.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: And with what credit they receive it!

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Were I sure, lying would always thrive thus,
I'ld make a vow never to speak truth more.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But at Court, Bernard.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A Lady, Sir, a handsome Lady too,
though her hoods hide part of her beautie,
Would fain have you to her self a while.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: To her self? why, what would she doe with me?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Was that a fit question for me to ask?
As if they would tell servants,
What they do with their Masters;
They are not so immodest, I hope.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Some of their stories would make me blush.
But this Lady looks with some honesty,
And desires to speak with you in private.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Wait on her in.
Step you two into that drawing room a little.
If there were some Astrologie i'th' visit now.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I hope 'tis the Astrologer the Ladie makes it to.
You want such Visitants.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: You must wittily and boldly chiause two or three,
And then you'l be in Vogue indeed.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What ere it be from hence you may observe us.

div.stage: Enter Celia, Fannie, Luce, Shift, Rawman.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Are you not surpriz'd at the confidence of such a visit?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I'm honour'd with it, Madam, beyond measure honour'd.
Beshrew me 'tis a fair Lady indeed, a very fair one.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I hope, Sir, I han't so little skill in beautie,
But you may take my word for a good face.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Trust me, I do not see a better.
How may I serve you, Ladie? how may I deserve
The pains y'have taken thus, to find me out?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To see Endimion I would have done more;
With such impatience did I long to be
Acquainted with the Genius of the age;
The learned'st Man our England ever bred.
Oh Luce! I tremble; I shall never have courage
To utter what I come about.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What need you speak at all? he can understand you
By signs and tokens, as well as he were deaf and dumb.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Madam, I want expressions to return
A Complement so ill-deserv'd, 'tis true
I have some slight tincture of knowledge, but—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nay, nay, your modesty is fruitless, I know your abilities.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: This esteem is too obliging, Ladie; but could I serve you,
I should value my self too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh Endimion!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What means that sigh?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You might save me the shame of being truch-man to't.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: She's in love w'ee.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: By my Astrologie I would she were,
On condition I had forfeited all my Interest in the stars.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: The knowledge y'are so envied for
Of my desires cannot leave you ignorant.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: S'lid, would you have her make love t'ee down-right?
And she'd say but half as much to me,
I'd understand her, I warrant you:
Y'are the strangest Man.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: So you would have had her-a-told us her errand too:
Yes, I warrant you.
Women love to do that they won't say;
Some pretty things have but course names.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: By that very reason, Lady, that you give
For your silence, you ought to speak your mind;
If I know a'ready what brings you hither,
Your free declaring it to me ought not
Add any thing to your confusion.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Excellently well argued! what fending & proving here is?
He's cried up for a wit, and the Wench
Will laugh at him for a fool, a dull one.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I had best talk to her for the credit o'th' house.
That she may see there's some quickness
Of apprehension i'th' family, some feeling left.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What can the hearing of my weakness avail you?
You know the languishing desires I'm prest withall,
My coming t'ee, my standing thus before you,
Thus blushing and discountenanc'd, does speak my mind;
Use me not then with so much cruelty, but since
Bashfulness hinders me naming my request,
Do what I would have you, without my saying what.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Pray do, Sir, without more bidding.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I see, you are not free to strangers, Sir,
I could have made an Interest you would not have refus'd
Any courtesie the stars make you Master of.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: 'Tis clear now; some Astrologicall question
She has to put me.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Y'are e'en well enough serv'd, and't be,
That would not understand her other meaning.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: She'I shift her arrant now, and invent something
To plague you with, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Would she had made Shift her arrant,
She had sped better.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Very likely.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Is she mad, to expect I should know her thought?
Am I a Magician, or am I the devil himself to do't?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: If it be Astrologie, some bombast words
She cannot understand, will quickly put her out of play,

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Unmannerly fellows, they are these Conjurers,
They will not satisfie a Ladie without so much intreatie.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I'Id e'en leave him, Madam, and go to another▪
What little pyed devil's that, whispers with him?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis his Man.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: His Zanie, his Jack-Pudding;

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: 'Tis some quack this, I warrant you, some Mountebank.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Peace, he comes towards us.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Wrap your Answer in Fustian, Sir, 'tis a warm wear,
And will look gravely.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Not to belye my science, Madam, or uncivilly pretend
An ignorance, you'l not believe me guilty of,
I must confess, 'tis easie scrutiny for me
To dive to th' bottom of your heart, and read
What's most abstruse.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: D'ee see now? I knew he could tell.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Yet 'twere in vain I should Endeavour ought
For you, unless by a Declaration
Free and sincere, you testify
Your sull consent to what I go about;
You would try my skill first; but take heed this
Diffidence you shrowd with modesty,
Do not impede the compassing your wish;
A Frank confidence, a strong credulity
Is required in those apply themselves
To such as I am for relief; my art's
Beyond the Vulgar of Judiciary Astrologers:
Which clearly to evince, I will (if you
Desire it) tell you what your thought is, now,
This very minute; what brought you hither,
Whether your heart be free, or if engag'd,
To whom, how long y'have liv'd so; or what else
You think or wish most secret: but this done,
No more; I can do nothing for you then.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How I shall blush at this recital, you
Condemn me to?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I'ld tell him nothing, and 'twere to me;
Are you sure he'I keep your counsel?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What do I save by that, when he can know't however?
I love, Endimion; and he that captives me,
Having by Amorous duties won my heart,
Forsakes me then to travel into France,
So scornfully, he never takes his leave;
This Letter though I have just now receiv'd,
As kind as he was wont to be himself,
Which new assurance of his love, makes me
Passionately now wish his return;
I burn to see him, and though what I long for
Seem impossible, yet am I well assur'd
To you 'tis so facile, you may this night
Feast my sad Eyes with that beloved sight.
If ever Love then warm'd your youthful heart,
As your own flames may kindle mutual fire,
Deny not my request.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Here's a request with a vengeance,
Would gravel all the Conjurers of the Realm.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: It had been as easie, I should think now,
Taking her up at her first weapon,

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I hou dost run on still with thy own conceit,
And never thinkst of helping me out of the mire.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Shall I fetch Charles his Wain to draw you out?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: And yoak Phaebus's horses to't,
That the Teem may be strong enough.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Call upon Nostradamus, Sir, he was your Master, 〈…〉 (remov'd
He's bound to help you for his own credit.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: The old Man with his hard words was not half so terrible.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Tell her, she must make a pact with the Devil,
That will skare her.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I know not, Madam, who you take me for,
Nor what you may imagine of my Art,
For where is't like that I this night should find
A Man, that you your self tell me's in France?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That's a matter of nothing to you,
You do things more prodigious howerly,
I know that, to make one long since depriv'd
Of life, both speak and move, is slight
And easie t'ee; I have it, from good hands.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: No doubt but you have; and I durst have sworn.
Y'had bin an eye witness yourself too
Of some of these Miracles.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I had rather talk to her o'th influence
Of her Eyes now, then of that o'th Stars.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Oh, had you so?
But you are not to chuse your own Text by
Your favour, Sir, she has set you a Theam.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Th' impossibility of your request pleads my excuse,
There is no power in all my Art to serve you,
If you command the presence of an absent person.
Such things are not done by pure Astrologie,
Spectres and Phantasms move by Magick only,
Which black and dismal study, as it lies,
Within the compass of the Law, ne'r is th' application
Of a noble mind; besides a Ghost or Vision
Cloath'd in a fantastick body, is too melancholly
For your Sex and Age, such dire Apparitions,
As they are full of horror in themselves,
Strike pale with it, the stoutest looker on,
Your courage would fail you too at such a sight,
And you'ld repent the courtesie obtain'd.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh never, Sir, if the kind Specter have
My beloved's shape; be it but like him,
And the sweet vision will more please then fright,
But you mistrust me still, and think a Woman
Unfit for such a secret.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: He has been very cautious hitherto
Of trusting the Sex with any of that Nature,
And I think he has not many of 'em for you neither.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nothing less, Madam, and since you urge me to't,
I have, perhaps, skill enough for what you desire.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh Luce, 'twill come at last.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Hang him, Wizzard, I'ld see him swim to th' Devil
With a Milstone about his neck, e're I would Court him thus,
Or be beholding to him indeed.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: If I did at first plead an impossibility
To obey you, 'tis for a certain obstacle
I find in't, a main one too, your Lover, you tell me,
Is in France, and there's the mischief on't,
The Sea divides us, and I have no power
Beyond my own district, the wild Element
So uncontrouledly opposes all my charms
My hands are tyed; and that's the true
And only cause, I've dallied we'e thus long.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nay, if that be all, th'impossibilitie none,
That obstacle of the sea is easily remov'd,
So the fresh water hinder not, and if it do,
We'l cross the River, this Letter here
Is dated from Dover, see.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, I believe you, Madam. worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: From whence he writes, he'l not stir of some days,
He wav'd the Packet-boat, and waits a Man of War;
He has some business too in Kent, some friends to see.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I am gone; this bold Wench with her mettle
Has conjur'd that Devil out of me, others
Think I have at my fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Does my Master think they take him for a Taylor?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know he's not ship'd yet;

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Would she were sunk some Fathoms with her fellow,
To cool her courage, 'tis such a Virago.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Bellamy's suppos'd on's way for France,
What if 'twere he now she long'd for a sight of?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That's not unlikely, this may be Celia too;
I'le sift it out, e're I engage too far.
If he be yet on English ground, let me
But know his name, for in that Circumstance
Your Confession's yet defective, not that
I'm ignorant of't, for let me tell you,
Though his Birth be good, his Name as ancient,
The Familie's decay'd in Means, his personal
Gallantry making good the worth of Ancestors
Whose I and he ne'r inherited.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That is his Character.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nor do we differ much in age, though he
Perhaps, be something of the fairer stature.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It is most true.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, then I'm well enough.
You'l think it strange now, when I know the Man,
I should ask you his name, but I have reasons for't;
Such, as unless I have it from your mouth,
I can't comply with your desires; 'tis an Essential
Ceremony, a kind of deference our Art expects.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How pleasing 'tis to me to speak that name!
Bellamy, now you have it; what else
Must I do, or say to obtain my suit?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: The sea not awing then my charms▪
There's no pretence left to deny you now;
And were the Task yet harder then it is,
Your Confidence would win me to't,
So daring a Spirit, that seeks what hardiest Men
Durst not attempt, would ever make me try
My utmost, look me full i' th' face.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh happy Celia!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Let me see your hand, what day were you born on?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: The Tenth of May.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What day of the week?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: On a Saturday.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: She does not look, Luce, as she had bin made up
On a Saturday in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You must see your Sweet-heart then,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To night, if it be possible,
The very thoughts of it transport me so.—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You must make me a Covenant with his Idea now.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Oh Cosen! will you turn Covenanter now?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: When they that set the Idol up
Have pull'd it down themselves.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Nay, 'Tis burnt, they say, 'tis burnt.
He'I make you a Phanatick i' th' end
And you hearken to him, with his idle Idea's.

sp.speaker: Lu
sp.l: As I am here, this is one of the Devils Trapanners,
And has a standing Fee of so many fresh
Familiars per annum from the Prince of darkness.
To wheedle young ones in.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: This malepert tongue will draw a vengeance on't,
If you beware not, Minion.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: You must excuse her▪ Sir, 'tis a mad Wench,
She will talk thus of her Mistress, or my
Mother, or any one sometimes.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Your tongue's but little better govern'd neither
For all your excuses.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Let em talk their fill here among friends,
But not a word of Conjuring abroad▪
D'ee mark me, Gentlewoman, not a word,
Or by my Jacob's-staff— but go to.
The Covenant I desire is wholly harmless,
An innocent Charm, and I must needs have
A ticket written with your own hand.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: In bloud, Sir? End. No, no.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Can I refuse any thing that may contribute
To what I so much long for?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: My figure once made, and the Mystery finish'd,
I'le tear your note, indeed I will;
My Standish here, and some Paper.
sp.stage: they set a table with Lights and Paper—

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: What think you now, Luce?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I think he's a Conjurer still, as I may tell you,
Amongst our selves, for I dare call him so
Aloud no more, he swears by such a strange thing,
The Prime Minister of State to the subterranean Monark.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But what sayst thou to my note?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This very night will he carry it to the
Meeting-house, and pin it to the goat's tayl.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: You are sure i'th' next Lampoons to be coupled
With Lucifer, you shall be the sole couple in hell
For me, I'le nere write to him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Flat and plain, Mistress, he should have
Nothing under my hand, I say.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Away, away, thou art too scrupulous.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Write, as I'le dictate t'ee.
sp.stage: takes her aside toth' table where she sits to write

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Shall you & I chop a little Logick now,
My blowing bud of beauty.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: E'en as little as you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: My most undelicate Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: On further acquaintance, you'I say, the more the better; for though I serve such a terrible Master, I can be as familiar, as impudently familiar as any little Rogue of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Thou hast thy sinful extream too, I see.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Yet their Talent lies the more natural way,
