I should like it the better of the two,
But thy Master is so dreadfully learn'd.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Beyond all thou seest yet;

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: One must carry their body swimming
With him that knows the heart By looking in the face.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: If he hear but one's name, 'tis enough.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: That's stranger yet.
Know people's thoughts, and hear but their names?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: He never goes without a little devil in's pocket
For that purpose, which he calls his Vade mecum:

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: A devil always about him, and you serve this man?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why not? the devil's no ill company sometimes,
I mean a familiar one:

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Alas, we have whole Covies of tame fiends;
Why there's the devil of Mascon,
Would you wish a more sociable Goblin?
You have heard of him, the storie's in English.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I have not seen it.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Why, then I'le tell thee, 'tis a smug young fiend
Made love to a Parson's daughter.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Or his Maid,

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: True, for in that particular Authors disagree.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: As they do about Statira the Wife of Alexander, whether she were the Daughter, or Widow of King Darius.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou art read in History too.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Not much.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But prythee how did the devil court his Mistress,

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Would he do her work for her, as the tales
Go of sprights and fairies?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: That I have forgot, but I'le give you the book to satisfie your Curiosity: This I remember, he had a damnable mind to a certain red ribbon she wore somewhere; but the niggardly old Parson would not let her give it him, for which don devil most zealously reprov'd his want of Charity.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: But what if thy Master's devil should creep to my Cousin now?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How should we be troubled with her at home?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: That need's not.
A handsome Woman's devil enough of her self,
Besides by her sharp look I guess her a shrew,
She needs no devil to teach her to scold.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: She did so jet it too as she came in,
So eye her self, I see she's proud;
There's another o'th' devils good qualities,
She's not beholding to my Master for.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Why, thou studiest the black art too then?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Physiognomie a little, 'tis Physiognomie tells all this.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Your name is wanting still, subscribe it, and I've done.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And is this all?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: All, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I leave it w'ee: think on me, Endimion;

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I never yet broke promise to handsome Lady,
Nor will I now begin with you, fair one.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, don't tell my Cosen, 'twas I had her Apricocks; and I'le steal you some to morrow, and sing you a fine song too.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, without a bribe I can keep counsel, pretty one.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I'm undone, if he look me i'th' face now;
I have anger'd him, and these Witches are
sp.stage: holds her Apron before her face.
sp.l: So revengeful.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You hide your face from me now, and I see your heart.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Oh, Sir, I'le never call you Conjurer more,
Nor speak true word of you again, but if
You know what I now think, as you are frail
Your self, keep it from my Mistress, she'd turn
Away Ralph infallibly, and she knew it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: How much ado have I had to shake her off?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: You have been something long about it indeed.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: This bold cheat will fame you straight
For eminently skill'd;
And your renown will every where increase.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I never suffer'd so hot a persecution.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Nor I so tedious an Expectation.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I'm sure I sweat for't again.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I durst not laugh neither.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: How modestly he declin'd her commendations? and yet the very carelesness you received 'em with, perswaded her, you thought you well deserv'd 'em.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Why harp'd you not on the Ceremonious string still?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I saw she came not for a Compliment.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Why struck you not in, in your advisor's way?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Less on that account too.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: That was the Common road.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: It was not hers, you see.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I never was so put to't contein my self,
As when she prov'd her Lover was on English ground,
And whip'd off the salt water.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I confess, I was put to't my self then;
I was almost non-plust.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: I hearkned still when she'd bespeak a bridge
Over to Callice; but what if we had
Not been in an Island now? what if there
Had been some way over Land into France.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: If there had, 'tis odds she'd not find it out;
For 'twere I think another wonder, she
Should be more knowing in Cosmographie,
Then I am in Astrologie:
At worst I had found out some other Evasion,
Pleaded the difference of Religion—

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Marry, and a good plea too.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Or I know not what my self now.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I think so; but the letter, what's that?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: No secret; but prythee
Who should this Mother be the young one mention'd once,

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh the Widow Aunt, I told you Celia liv'd with.

body.l: Bellamy I know where you are,
Pretence of travels, vain and light.
And you are not yet got so farre,
But I may see you here this night.

sp.l: A most elaborate Epistle, full of rithme and reason:
And much you can do with it no doubt.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: We must convey it into Bellamy's hands,
Who suspecting by 't he has been dogg'd, or
Is found out indeed, will hast to Celia
For his vindication, and so betray
Himself; I am reveng'd by this means of
Clarinda, whose night-works I destroy: and
If it happen that Celia full of spirits still
And apparitions, take him for one, and
Dare not give him hearing, no trick, no plot
We could contrive, will add more credit to
What's of my Astrologie already spread.
All the business is to deliver this note.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Leave that, Sir to my care

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Your care? is that a fit Province
For a Raw-man? I'le take charge on't my self.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, no Vying; I must use you another way,
But it must be delivered to his own hands.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: So I intend it shall. End. But how?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Without much cunning thus: Clarinda waits
Him in her garden to night, tis near the
Hour too, in's road I'le lye perdu, and if
I do not make lam change his Rendezvous.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: No better way could be imagin'd.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Dispatch then, and bring us tydings on't.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: That I shall speedily, and good one's too, nere fear it.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: GOod Sir, nay, but consider.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The more I do, the more I find you a trouble some fellow.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: But I always was of your midnight Counsels,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And that blazes 'em abroad at noon-day.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Was I ever heard to say, my Master has left such a Ladie, such a one's his Mistriss now; he treated this Madam at that place, and t'other Madam at t'other place?—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: If you had, sirrah, I had been seen to beat you.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I don't talk o'that; there's no bodie questions your aptness that way.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Will you get you home?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: After you is manners, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I shall beat you home.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: What again beating? some other time, some other time may serve, you have business of more concern in hand now to my Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Your Knowledge?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: You sleep not all day, to ramble all night for nothing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Ramble, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Nay, I observe you, when I don't follow you? 'tis for no good you hide your self from Madam Celia thus. She has deserv'd Better of you; who did I bring you the Two hundred pounds from, when you were snapt at Mr Grogram's suit of Pater-Noster-Row? Or who fills your Pockets again when your Dice run the children of lee, or Deuce ace is your Comfort? Many a Ladie has more comfort of a cheaper Gallant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Are you that Ladie's Dun, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Her kindness will soon ha▪ done, and 't be no better requited, then are we undone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Excellent! quibbles too.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: You may get preferment however i'th' next forlorn expedition: 'twill be sad reducing your Coach, Horses, and Lacqueys to a sixty pound per annum Equipage.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Thou art my Pedagogue sure, my Tutour.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: I am your poor Valet de Chambre, Sir; one that would gladly have his Master wise enough to grow rich, that he may thrive under him: refuse a handsome Ladie, and a good fortune, when they are offer'd, to ferret after Je we scay quoy's?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou hast not thy name for nothing, I see; th' art e▪ en the Rude Serving-man, it speaks thee.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: I am honest, Sir, if I am bold, I do not flatter and cheat you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: One of 'em I'le swear thou do'st not; but for the other, Rud, I'le swear,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I shan't be rid of this fellow now, and aside. Looks on's watch. my hour draws near. I know him close and secret as the night, however I seem shie of him. Come, I will trust thee for once; as we go, I'le tell thee whither; but follow me, d'ee hear, and direct me not.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Oh any thing, Sir, to make one.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This fellow's one of those are scandaliz'd at all wickedness they have not a hand in, and cannot abide any Man should Drink or Wench without 'em.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: And some such exploit, I suspect you bound for now.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I should guess you do by your earnestness to make one.
Nay, this way, this way.

div.head: SCENE III. The back-side of Sr Christopher 's Garden.

sp.p: I Long to have done my arrant now, to see how heartily, how gamester like, he'll fret to loose the kisses he thinks himself so fair for to night? how many ten groats will he swear himself out of, if any of the godly be but within hearing? I must pack as soon as I have deliver'd the Letter, for coming in Celia's name, the thanks he'd give, won't be worth staying for. I cannot be far from the Garden now, here will I stand sentinel: he knows me not, and so there is no danger of an after-beating.
I hear some bodie, 'tis he certainly.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Nay, if Clarinda love you too, I'm satisfied, she's rich enough to do our business, but here's a father's good will to get; the other's at her own dispose.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Time may work him▪ who's there?

div.stage: runs against Sh. as going into the garden

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A friend, Sir, that waited your coming:
This note from Celia speaks my business,
She earnestly desires your Company to night:
And I am your Worship's servant.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: An unserviceable one, he thinks, at this time.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What curst Encounters this? honest fellow, Friend, prythee a word. Rudeman, stay the fellow.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: He's gone, he's out of my reach; but that's no hard matter indeed, for I never had any great reach with me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Venturing at wit, when I am thus perplext.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: The night's so dark too, he's as soon out of sight.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Again?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: What devil has discover'd you were in town?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Or what faithless confident rather betrays
My secret? 'tis Gratian, it can be none
But he, I trusted none else, and he loves
Celia too,
In whose affection to supplant me now,
He has betray'd my privacie:
I have deserv'd no less to trust a Rival;
That title once succeeding dissolves
All former tyes of friendship.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: To be snap'd here too at the garden door
Brings Clarinda in question.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: That's meer accident; Gratian, though he knew
I conceal'd my self, knew not wherefore,
And she would nere betray me.
Some speedy balsome though I must apply
Where he has us'd such Corrosives: I will
To Celia, she loves me, with ease I can
Pacifie her, and destroy those rash hopes
A false friend has conceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: But what is this note were not from Celia now?

div.stage: stayes him as he was going off.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: The Messenger I know not,
Nor had he any mind I should.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: So farre it smells knavishly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: First let me see, if't be her hand, and then
With all the kind words, Credulous Maids lend
Greedy ear unto, I will make my peace.
If light discover it a mistake, or trick,
I'le forward to Clarinda, where
A thousand kisses shall make amends
For staying thus beyond my hour?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Marry, would I were to do the penance for you.

div.head: SCENE IV. Celia 's Chamber. A Table and Lights set forth, a Chair by't.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: CAn you imagine this star-wright with all his hard words, should bring Bellamy so far on such a sudden?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Silly wretch! thy shallow understanding
Cannot reach the bottom of his Capacity,
Which, (so the sea lye not in's way) will do
A thousand things harder and stranger, he'll
Come then, never doubt it, not he himself
'Tis true, but his similitude,
Something resembling him so perfectly,
Love it self could not make a distinction.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What good will that Copy of his Countenance do you?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Ask Love if thou be'st ignorant, for he is
The reason of all he forces us to,
Nor is the Curiosity so strange,
In me, nor so particular;
I've heard of many Women use the like.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: 'Twere a strange thing indeed Women in this town would not venture upon. I have heard too of the Woman of Billeter-Lane, and of her of Grub-street.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: And of Ladies that go into Chancery-Lane to know when their husbands will die, whether their next will be kinder.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: And what day o'th' week is best to be married on: but bless me from such pranks, they are no handsome leans melancholy on the table. one's, I'm sure, though the handsome Ladies use 'em.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But, Madam, you are heavie, the very thought
Of this apparition, works upon you
Like th' expectation of an ague-fit.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Shall I sing you a song, Cosen, to divert sad thoughts?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I prythee, Fannie, 'twill chear thee,
However it work on me.

lg.l: Thus the white bull that does Europa bear
Shrouding Jove's person does his Love defect:
Send him to Danae in a shower.
If 'mong the gods he bear this sway,
What can he not o're Mortals doe?
He that with Deities thus dares to play,
Will govern sure Mankind as strangely too:
Nor is the fairer sex more free

sp.l: For women once:—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'le hear no more; there's none so strange as mine,
As that my Bellamy's expected in,
Others had the substances they lov'd, though
Cloath'd with accidents they were not us'd to,
But I must be content with th'outward shape
Of what I love, shrouding I know not what
Substance or reality.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But if it be a Phantasm, a bodie
Patch'd up of air or grosser Vapours,
Will not you be afraid, think you?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not in the least.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I'm sure but I shall then.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Heark, some bodie knocks at door.

div.stage: starting off the table she lean'd on.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Some bodie, quoth you?
We neither look for bodies nor souls here,
What if 'twere the I know not what now?
The strange thing you'l call Bellamy?
You grow pale already, you sigh too.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Is this the Courage love puts into his?
I think he's a Coward himself for my part
And he back you with no better mettle now in time of need.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You think 'tis he now.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am not certain, but see who ere it be.
I'm strangely chang'd o'th' sudden, I feel not
That firm resolution now, my soul is
Seiz'd with horrour, that strikes a shivering cold
All o're my body, something there is in
Nature still repugns against these Visions,
Maugre the love or humour sets one on.
But what need I fear?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Oh Madam, Madam, 'tis he, 'tis Bellamy,
sp.stage: drops the candle out of her hand and runs away.
sp.l: But that he's twice as tall as he was wont to be.

sp.speaker: Cel. Fan.
sp.l: Ay me! Ay me!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What means this shreeking and this running about?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Now am I well paid for my Curiosity, I have at the far side of the stage. my wish, and 't proves my own undoing, 'tis Bellamy's Voice, but I han't power to answer him.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I'm nothing mistaken in my self,
sp.stage: from under the table, where she had hid her self.
sp.l: I knew I should be afraid, and my Cosen
For all her cracking proves as very a Coward.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: When I besought th' Astrologer to send him to me,
I wisht to see him onely, not to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Send for me, Celia, and use me thus. 'tis something strange?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: If the thing should find me under the table now.
I'le pray hard.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Could you find no body else to practise
These Exotick fits upon? must I be
Your ridiculous mirth, that bring my Celia
New assurances, 'tis she alone
Has power in Bellamy's heart?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'le ha none of thee, nor thy heart,
I abhor the power, 'tis the true Bellamy I had a mind to see.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: She suspects my inconstancy;
I am to Celia the same Bellamy still,
My thoughts of thee are nothing chang'd, I vow.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Fiend keep off, avant Phantasm; get runs into her closet, and shuts her self in. thee to France again, or into Lapland, from whence thou camest, I think.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Hear but my reasons. is't rallerie this?
Or some trick devis'd on purpose to make
Trial of me? Fannie, what doe'st thou there?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Help, help, I'm kill'd, I'm done to death getting hastily from under it. with fear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Was ever Gallant thus gallantiz'd?
sp.stage: throws it down candle and all, runs away and leaves him i'th' dark.
sp.l: The devil o-love, and this be it, I say.
Fiend, and Phantasm, and Lapland! I am not
Mad sure, though they be; I'le try'em again;
Luce, Celia, why Luce, prythee prevail with
Thy Mistress to hear me. Celia, Fannie,
Pretty, Sweet Fannie: 'tis labour lost;
I shan't be answer'd, unless there be an
Eccho within hearing, the dumb devil
Possesses 'em, and I am left i'th' dark
To grope out the meaning of this frolick.
Well, let her have her humour, I must to
Clarinda, and prevent what ill offices may be
There intended too, I am discovered
In town, and need not now keep out of sight,
Pray heaven the morn prove kinder then the night.

div.head: The first SCENE, Sr Christopher 's house.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: SO deep a melancholy does both surprize,
And grieve me, Sweet; what makes these sighs so frequent?
Can you doubt my fidelity?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I'm full of fears, I must confess it, Bellamy;
Nor can I, when I think what enemies we have,
Though you are present, force a chearfulness.
What will not Endimion, knowing all
We thought most secret, attempt to ruine us:

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: He can do nothing, if you love me still.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Would I could say so of Celia too!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh Madam! you are too injurious—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Our first affections nere loose all their power;
Call your kindness for her a civil devoir,
A gratitude if you will; she is lovely still,
And Civility forces you to see her:
Then smother'd flames too-easily break out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Wrong not your own charms, and my affection
With so unjust a Jealousie:
If you can so much slight Clarinda's power
To fear Celia; I'le not see her at all.
But I am not without my fears neither,
For who loves tenderly, and thinks himself secure?
What will your father say, when once he knows
You suffer Bellamy's love, or what will
He not do to ruine a happiness
He thinks me not rich enough to deserve?
He'll chide, he'll school Clarinda, he'll threaten her,
If she neglect his lessons, will she not
Fear his anger? and in that fear, in that
Fear perhaps she will forsake me,
And wrought of his own mind, hold it
A madness where an Estate is wanting,
To value Birth, descent, or Breeding—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Think better of me, then so. Know that the
Vertue of the belov'd object alone
Is enough to make me constant, that worth
Which first made me love, makes me persever.
Nor is my heart so much a slave to fear,
That Menaces can blot out an Image,
A noble affection had drawn in't.
No Bellamy, I shall wear yours here still.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I am too happy then.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Accept this pledge of my fidelity,
And be assur'd I'm yours;
Let friends, let fortune smile or frown,
Never shall Celia's constancy equal mine.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: My Joy is now so great, I am lost in't.
Unable to speak, unable to keep silence—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You must keep it a while; here's my father—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Is not that Bellamy? what return'd alreadie?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: An unexpected Law-suit forces me back,
I am sub-pena'd up again, and must
Till after term at least lay by all thoughts
Of seeing France; I was at Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: And how does my Nephew Manly?

sp.speaker: Reat.
sp.l: He may as well ask me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: He entertain'd me nobly at his house.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Has not the young-squire written to me? ha?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: He had, and gave me his letter, but a
French Lacquey I took here for the Journey,
When he saw me turn back, run away with
My Vallize, and your letter was in it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: That Lacquey saves thy credit now,
It must have been said to thee else.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: You have made but an ill journey on't then.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Thus are my stars still inauspicious to me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Endimion Madam at your request would
Tell him to his Vallize again.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Away thou cruel Wench, thou seest the pangs
This discourse gives me, and canst raise mirth out of it?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: My ownloss I should not value,

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: 'Twas not so great indeed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But the Letter was meerly writ on my behalf,
And did implore your aid in my affairs.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: You may command me, and my interest.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If you Espouse his Cause, he need not fear being cast.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: If the old Man Espouse his Cause,
The young one will Espouse you.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: And that's it she would be at.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Would 'twere come to't once for me,
That I might have some quiet among 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: On your favour then I build my hopes, but this
Law-business draws me uncivilly away,
Pleaders are not Masters of their own time.
Your pardon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Business must be waited on;

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: May I presume you'I mind your father
Of my suit, Madam, and contribute
To the continuance of his favours?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Ile do my best, Sir, to possess him with
The justice of your cause; his Example
Authorizes me to own your interest too.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: But wilt thou be thus melancholy still?
What is the cause? tell me, good Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I know no reason for't.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: She dreamt of a younger brother, Sir, to night,
Which, reflecting on Endimions prediction,
Seems ominous.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Your bolt is soon shoot still.
Art indispos'd in health?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I feel no alteration;
And yet it may be some natural overslow
Of a dull humour in the bodie causes this heaviness.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Ah Clarinda! my tenderness of thee
Is ill requited with this sullen reserve
Of thy sick thoughts..

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: To speak truth, I have lost some toyes, and that's
The onely reason I can give for this damp
My mirth is struck withall.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Why, what hast lost?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: That which does vex me much.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: But what?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The Rose-diamond you gave me.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Let not that trouble thee, it may be found again.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I have small hopes on't, I have sought every where.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: I was carelesly laid by perhaps,
And opportunity makes a true man a thief:
sp.p: But the loss is easily repair'd, there are fairer rings in town, I'le go buy thee one presently.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: That were a slight reparation of my loss;
I fancied this.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: What a fondness is here? though I give her
A better ring, she'l loose by the bargain:
Well, set thy heart at rest,
Thou shalt have thy own again, for I will
Just now to Endimion about it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Now you are in a fine Pickle!
To excuse these dumps y'are faln into,
Y'have gone and spoilt all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: So I have indeed.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Peace, peace; he's coming back.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Tell me, when was this ring lost?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I mist it but to day.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: So, so, 'tis not gone farre, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Further I hope, then your discoverie will reach.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: The old man's here again.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: But about what a clock was it lost? for I shall be askt all these questions, that I shall; therefore I must be prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Between eight and nine.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Oh 'tis well, 'tis well, eight and nine, eight and nine;
Let me not forget eight and nine.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: How he maunders it, eight and nine, eight and nine; he'l Con his lesson nine times over, but he'l have it perfect.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What shall I do, Beatrix? advise me, good Beatrix.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: 'Twere well and you would be adviz d, before▪
You do it, then Beatrix could say something,
But to be put still to an after-game,
You are so wilfully fore-handed:
This scurvy Astrologer now will tell him all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Endimion is the Man indeed undoes me▪
But let him do his worst, my love stands not
In awe now of a father's check, 'tis of
So fair a growth his frowns cannot nip it,
My heart is Bellamy's, nothing can force it from him,
Endimion and his Stars are all too weak?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: The devil is not so head-strong as these young Wenches, when they have got a bit of a Man; but 'tis I must lay the storm for all her vapouring; I must let Shift know how things go, least his Master be put to't beyond his skill, and shaking hands with Astrologie, be forced to tell our old man the plot.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: WHat a perpleity am I reduc'd to?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Why, 'twas with your consent,

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Nay, by your own order we rais'd the report.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Yes of Astrologie, but of nothing else,
And yet they think abroad, I have all hell
At command: They point at me i'th streets,
So noted a person I am.
There goes the learned Man, saies one; oh the
Astrologer, saies another, that comes
And peeps me in my face to know me again.
In some places they stare at me,

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: As they would have done at the hairy woman,
Had she not cas'd her beard up as she went about.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Right— or as they did at the Hermophrodite T'other day at the play.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: The Prophet, saies a precise one, and lifts
His hands and eyes to Heaven in admiration,
That one so young should be so knowing.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Children run away, and cry the Witch, the Witch, the Witch; because at home their Mothers fright them with him.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Thou boy, Rawman!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Some understanding ones there are, (and those
I forgive, because they are i'th' right)
Believe me guilty of no Magick, but
A meer Impostor, for such contemn me,
Laugh at me, and those that think me other.
Thus am I entertain'd i'th' streets;
Or thus at least I interpret their looks
And actions that I meet i'th' streets.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Some skill you have in Physiognomy,
It seems, (if you have none in Astrologie)
That can read all this in Men's faces.
But fame, you know, loves to augment every thing.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Nothing toth' People is a little rare,
They will hyperbolize, and skrue all novelties
To the highest Key: a lye with them
Snow-ball-like rowles about, and gets in every place,
Each teller of't adds something of his own,
To shape it to his fancie.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: If you are thus plagu'd abroad, you must keep
Home a while; the Wonder will be over.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: We cannot do that neither in quiet,
So many have found his Lodging out;
And now Moll Cut-purse that Oracle of felonie
Is dead, there's not a pocket pickt,
But hee's acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: That's much indeed.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Nor a silver hilt pincht away, but they come
To the figure-flinger for it.
sp.p: He hears of every Wedding, Christning, City-feast, by th' Butlers recourse to him for Plate and Linnen they lost at 'em.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: That's more yet.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Alas, I am a kind of grandissime Jurie, and have all thefts brought before me, before they go to Hicks-hall, or the Old Baily; marry, could I help the Man to his Mare again, they would never go thither, and I might take much of the matter out of the Lawyers hands: but all Trades must live, I'le not spoil theirs. I shall have the Country-fellows too with the savoury questions that poz'd old Noll's star-peeper, then am I in a sweet condition.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: The World is satisfied with your skill, 'tis grown a full and general persuasion.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I see nothing but mirth the stratagem has yet produc'd.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: What? to have Sir, and Madam; Cut and Long-tail put me a hundred several questions, as if I were Jupiter hammon, or Diana's spokes-man at Ephesus? you reckon this nothing? I never had too much of nothing till now.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Your Mistress by this fiction's aw'd,
Your Rival fears you too,
Their pleasures are disturb'd,
And all succeeds as you could wish it should.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Believe it Lewis, 'tis without regret
That I give Bellamy place, the disturbance
I bring his pleasures, yeilds me no content;
My own flames extinct, it concerns not me
Whether Clarinda meet his love, or no.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Here's an indifferencie I look'd not for.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: In affairs of love I measure ever the Esteem I make of Women, by that they make of me; where they incline to kindness, I can love too: if they withdraw once, or refuse their favours, my flexible and obedient heart, Lewis, can soon imitate: nor ever need I fower and twenty howers to cure my self of that disease.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I did mistake your temper; but since 'tis so convenient, why own'd you not the truth of all at first, without taking the Astrologer upon you?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You'l wonder at my stupiditie;
Nor can I now my self conceive, why I
Run my neck into this nooze, when all the danger
That threatned, was but the turning away
Of a Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Nere let it trouble you now, we bear our
Share of all, and owe a helping hand to
Bring you out, We help'd to plunge you in, and
Half the shame will fall on the divulgers.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have a quarrel to you, Endimion.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Here's my Virago again, 'tis th' importunest
Wench this, she'l never be answered. How can
I since last night have deserved your anger?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If Bellamy has not been absent, why
Would you, whose rare knowledge extends it self
To secrets more remote, make me one of
His being in town?
Why dealing with that candor you seem'd to
Promise, did you not tell me where he was?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What reason shall I give her? oh! I knew
It not my self till I made my figure;
Yet what if I had known it sooner? I
Promis'd but a sight of Bellamy, and
Did you not see him? consider but with
Equal Eyes the whole adventure,
No part of it but to my credit turns;
For if in lieu of an illusion, Madam,
A shade, a Phantasm you expected,
Spight of the care he took to hide himself,
I forc'd him though in person to appear,
Does it not prove the certain influence
Of an art.
You cannot now with want of power tax?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It does, I must confess, it does; this reason
Destroyes all Jealousies I had of it.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: You may be sure 'tis the best
He could find out for you oth' sudden.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But give my passion yet some further ease;
This Bellamy, this fair friend playes me fowl,
Those Vows forgot, I too much credited,
Pays a new Mistress what is due to me.
I have the storie of their close Amours,
And know the stars alone, which you command,
Witness their meetings and their kindnesses:
Break me this league then learned Endimion,
You that nere meet with obstacle to your will
But what your art orecomes;
Cancel the bonds she has my faithless in,
I'th' midst of her Caresses force him from
Her eyes; restore him to his true Mistress.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: No evasion does the Learning she so much admires
Inspire me now, but to perswade her she's mistaken.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Something from the learned Endimion will
Be expected, but that I think may serve

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Take better thoughts of your Lover, Madam:
Though in his carriage he may be too blame,
Yet are you misinform'd of what keeps him
In town, you are the cause of it your self,
To cure his Jealousie he thus plays least in sight,
And to observe you does pretend this Journey;
But since you are thus constant to him still,
Fear not his leaving you:
And should you of his Love want other proofs,
Let this suffice, that he is Jealous grown,
With a seeming coldness,
Or neglect perhaps he may dissemble
A while, but let it not disquiet you,
For 'tis you he loves, I say again,
And passionately.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pleasing hopes! comfortable assurance?
Pardon dear Bellamy if without Cause
I question'd thus thy faith; if Jealousie
Must prove thy Love, let my fears assure thee of mine,
I fear'd to loose but what I love to keep.
The heavens, kind Endimion, powre as many
Blessings on you, as y'have assur'd me of.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: She payes you in your own coin; as you have
Pleas'd her with an assurance of nothing,
She requites you with a wish of as much.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: 'Tis as believing a good Soul
As you'ld wish to preach to.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: And as well satisfied y'have sent her away,
Her heart I dare swear's as light as her head.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Her request did not much fright me this bout,
I knew that for a few fair words I should
Be rid of her credulous Ladieship.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But how intend you to make good your word
To Gratian? it seems alreadie broke by
The hopes y'have given Celia.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Why perceive you not those hopes are airie
Nothings with which I flatter her forwardness
To be fool'd? I know Clarinda
Has Bellamy too fast, to think
He ever will be Celia's, and this knowledge
Made me speak my own belief to Gratian.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Nay, he believes you too, and looks on me
His Introducer t'ee, as bound in honour for your performance,
Yet how you will, or can, I'm still to seek.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: In Love you are indeed.
Would you not judge else, that Celia
Needs must see at last how Bellamy fools her,
That she'l grow wearie of being thus abus'd?
If your friend then prove constant and persever;
Will not his services reach her heart i'th end?
Now if he give my art th' honour of an
Event, is due to his own industry
And the common Course of things,
The stars be prais'd for it,
But now we are free from these fortune seekers,
Let's breath a while, and talk of something else.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Not so free as you think neither; here's one—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Is worse then twenty Celia's.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Master Endimion.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Oh Sir! what wind blows you hither?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: An ill wind sure.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I thought so.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: But you will make it take about, and blow
Every one their own again, I must entreat
One Curtesie of you, kind Gentleman.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Excuse my boldness if I deal thus freely with you, and come to the point without any further compliment or preamble, I use no Ceremonie amongst friends?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I commend you for it, a civil freedom is much better.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: The loss of a certain Diamond has caused great disorder at home, my servants are suspected, and the whole family being in disturbance about it, my humble request is, you'l help me to set the saddle on the right house, that is you'l cast a figure for't, and tell who has it.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: The old Man comes in very good time to to End. break the truce you would have made with Astrologie.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I must break all commerce with it,
The chear s too gross to last above a day;
I ever told you so.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: He's musing on my request now.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: The trade he drives requires great recollection, 'tis a speculative trade, and I have often seen him on such occasions in so deep a study, you'ld think the soul did quite forsake the body, 'tis lest so void of action.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: He had more need to set all wheels awork, he must climb up to th' heavens for my ring, he'l nere find it here below else.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p:
I am not quit now for gulling an Amorous Maid, to Lew. or a more ignorant Lover, I must fool a man, who in that very toy I fool him with pretends to be as skill'd, as I am unacquainted,
and will discover my ignorance as soon as I pretend to knowledg. No, no, 'tis my own undoing to aside Lew and B. slighting him. play upon him any longer. I must deal freely, 'tis the onely way to get out of this plunge.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: See but what pains he takes.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: He's about your business all this while.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: He begins to look something seriously upon the matter.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Having no Interest to delude you, Sir;
I must confess there is much more believ'd,
Or said of me, then I deserve: 'tis true,
I have read something of Astrologie,
And view'd the grounds your Artists work upon,
Which makes some talking friends boast they have seen
Experiments beyond the common, though indeed
I ne're gave the least sign of a skill, they
Needs will force upon me, unless in words
Sometimes, yet sparingly, when their Example
Forc'd a compliance: but with you
I protest again, the reputation
This fiction gets me, nor all the merry
Consequences of it, can ne're force me
To such forgery; as for your Diamond then,
In vain expect you tydings of't from me,
'Tis out of my reach believe it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: He will fall to his natural Level
Of ignorance, I see, do what we can.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: And yet he cannot resolve to confess himself
An Impostor neither; he minces it a little.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Did I not know by the report of others, you are this day the Phoenix of Astrologers; this very humility with which you depress you abilities, would raise you in my Esteem above the common rank of Scholars.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Leave an opinion, I m not so happy
To deserve, I know nothing in the stars.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Who could forbear laughing at this old fellow, aside. that makes him take more pains to perswade his ignorance, then others do to get knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: This very earnestness with which you decline
The title of a knowing Man, tells me
Tis your due, and confirms me more and more
In the belief of your capacity.
Thus modest, thus discreet are they always
Who know much, nor will they, by assuming
Worth unto themselves, derogate from what
They do deserve, or by such gross Vanity
Eclypse the Lustre of their rare Endowments.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Our Astrologer has a fine time on't.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: You wish your self in his place, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: No, no, I have my share of the pass-time,
Where I am.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Were I indeed the Man you take me for,
Though I had reason to conceal my self from others,
Here I would yield my interest up to yours,
And with candour lay open all my skill,
But I have none, none at all to merit
The honour you doe me.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: I tell you again, that this humility alone is more commendable in you, then all your learning; he that knows most knows himself too well to be proud of what he knows, he sees too much daily to learn, to think that much he has alreadie learnt: and thus what art soever one pretend to, he that dares boast himself a Master of it, knows nothing in't at all.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Lyars, they say, loose credit even for the few truths they utter; but mine is a stranger punishment, when I lyed I was credited; and now I speak truth, I cannot win belief.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: But to come to my ring again, I must tell you (if that be a necessary Circumstance▪ 'twas a gift of my poor Wife's, for whose sake I long kept it, till at last Clarinda got it of me, and she bas lost it this morning, as she thinks, 'twixt eight and nine.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You shall have the other too at night, Sir.
Heark hither, this is but a pretext.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Why makes he so fine of it?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Hee's affraid perhaps of being suspected of Witchcraft; 'tis a detracting age, and he had need be cautious.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: He's over-nice with me, I can keep Counsel, and would conceal what were not fit for every Ear.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: This did Beatrix tell me just now.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Th' intelligence comes luckily, I was caught else.
Pardon the freedom, Sir, I take, to leave you
For an account of business I had sent
My man about, I should not trespass thus,
But that it did require some hast.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Would you had trespass'd, that you might expiate it With the Curtesy I request.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I am provided for him now,
And since he has a mind to 't, have at him;
Had I but skill enough.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Skill enough for a ring? away, away;
sp.p: There's nothing easier, then to help one again to such a toy as that, I could have don't my self at your years:

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I must yield by degrees, he'l suspect me,
If I pass suddenly from one extream
To another. Sir, I protest again
Without dissimulation—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Without dissimulation, or procrastination,
Good Sir, tell me to my ring again;
For I know you can, if you list now?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I did but spare you some trouble, declining
Thus to tell you what I find;
But since you needs will have it,

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Tell me, tell me, ' tshall ne're trouble me, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: He that this morning saluted you in
A riding garb, is the Man; he has it.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Who would have suspected him of all the world? that a Man of his birth and breeding should play such pranks, Necessity perhaps drives him to't;

And that We know having no Law it self, makes those that feel it, Lawless too. You see Endimion, how much in vain you go about to hide that, which in your very looks I read; when
once, I say, That Man's a Wit, a Scholar, he's one indeed. But fare you well Sir, I'le go after my ring.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: You stuck scurvily, till Shift helpt you out.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Never more, I swear; I knew not what shift to make.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Twas well for you there was one made to your hand.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Marry, was it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But what if he fall out with Bellamy now,
As having stoln his ring?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Nay, what if he charge him with felonie?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: And the Constable with him?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That were a jest indeed.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: What matter whether he take him for a son-in-law, or a thief, 'tis much at one; both lye at the catch for the old Man's Money, both (if 'tis not otherways to be had) watch his death for it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Though hitherto the sport does mainly thrive;
Checkt by no obstacle but such, as the
Removal of, turns to increase of mirth,
I'm wearie of a trade I nere was 'prentice to;
To leave it then with credit as I drive
It on, since the persuasion of my
Knowledge makes this old Man believe
What e're I say, I'le work on his facility
To a noble end, and farre from Jealous
Of a Rivall's fortune, will crown his Love
With the good Knight's allowance of Clarinda's.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hey day! all this busle for a Willow Garland?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: If I must wear one, I will have added to't, both Groom and Bride's free and grateful acknowledgment, 'tis I unite them, and that to my pretended skill i'th' stars they owe their happiness.
But who have we here? a new Consulter?

sp.speaker: Bern
sp.l: An old one, I think.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Nay! We have more Chamber-practice then half the Lawyers in town; yet the devil a fee or feeling I get amongst all our Clients:

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: This 'tis to serve a Generous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p:
That does all for God-a-mercy, and the credit of doing it,
and cries a good deed carries its own reward along with it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Peace Preacher.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Prythee what old Don is it?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: 'Tis a Monsieur, Man, has serv'd Sr Christopher Credulous ever since his travels, he brought him a young fellow out of France with him, Monsieur La-gripe.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: A griping Sir, I warrant him,

sp.speaker: La-gr.
sp.l: Ah Monsieur de Astrologue.

sp.speaker: Sh. and Raw.
sp.l: Monsieur La-gripe.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: For Clarinda sake, Clarinda our common Mistress they smile.— dat is te Mistres of us bote, serve for Love, serve for Money, for de Vages, Vat you call? it is all one, it Ise serve still.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Has he not made it good?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Not good English, Sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Good Pedlar's French, Sir, and that's better for Variety.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Hear out his storie.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: If I didde dare praye you of one faueur.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Very small petite chose, de no tingue.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But what? I'le do any thing for thee, honest Monsieur,

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Doe that den, I pray youe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That? what? I will and I can.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Oh if you can; Vraiment it is no if's nor Ans.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Can I unless you tell me what you would have done?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: No laugh at me, one poor old French man, pourquoy demande Vat, Ven you can as Vell tell, Var I say have done, as you can doe.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: May be so too.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vat you tinke me no knoe Vat you can doe? as if me no hear my old Master, my fellow Beatrige, and all te town besides talk of you.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But doe you hear I can know another's
Thought without his intimation?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I hear no intimation; Vat I hear, I know;
I no know dat.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Can a man deuine your meaning?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p:
Devine my mean? you look in my visage, you knoe
all, and yet I tell you notingue; you be no man to tell long storie to; derefore no aske me Vat I uould, but doe vat I uoude.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I shall be hard enough for thee yet, old fox.
'Tis not with thee Monsieur I would dissemble
My knowledge or my power; such palliations
Of an unkind repulse derogate—

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Ah Monsieur! no hard vords, I pray you, Pallashons! de gros cat! Vat te divell is dat to me? Plain English is hard enough for me, I promise you. How you think I entend dose sayings? I have no devell but thirty years in dis Contry.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Why, plainly thus then; I know what brought thee hither, and what thou wilt request of me!

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Oh, oh! look you dere den! me know very vell vat I say, I varrant's you; me no drunk.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: But soft: though I doe, I must not tell, nor use that knowledge for ought thou seekst of me, the reason's this; I can do but one thing for thee at a time: if then to read or tell thy thought be it, never expect me serviceable to the procurement of that wish, that is a second act, my hands are tied from at this t me.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Nay den, me tell you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Discover his wish to day, and help him to't to morrow. Where were you now Sir, if my Monsieur should come upon you thus?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: A French man, and stay till to morrow? That's a thing was never heard of; delayes are not for them, they nere got by 'em.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I be quite tired out uitte service here in England, tired as one Jade, uerefore me have a great mind, to return to me own poor Contry agen, to lay it my bones at home, and te money me scrape up in dis; but begare it be one uery Long Journie, and uery dangerous too, danger upon te Sea, danger upon te Eaise; I be rob here or dere, no like dat uery uell, be kill'd, assassined, or drown in te sea, begare like that uery uorse: an dat is te reason I come pray you, to secure my personne, and my purse, by some Enshantement, I no know how, to transporte me at my home in one minute.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh Excellent Monsieur!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: You see by this what they think of me Sh. and Raw. whisper. abroad. Pray heaven I don't take my self at last for that I'm given out for, these are strong temptations.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: And so become a wise man by fancying Sh. whispers with End. your self one;

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: As, they say, they do Witches, by strongly conceiting themselves Witches,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I ha' skill enough for this feat without my Master's meddling in't, I'le convey thee into France.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Prepare your self against night, Monsieur for the Journey; Shift shall be readie too with what on our part is necessarie.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I no dare truste him, littell Coquin delny,
Play me some tricque or toder.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: No, no; his fellow Rawman there shall go
Along too, and see fair play. Let's leave 'em
To their work, and laugh at him a little.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Mister sirrah, doe for me vat must be done
Fair and honest, your Master command;
You meddell in dis business de juggle too den.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I'm half a Conjurer, since I serve him,
And yet I came to him but a Rawman t'other day.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: An he parboil your Coxecombe?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Pickle him a little in the black art, or so.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Indeed? but is he so knoing, tey say?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hear him talk of a Man
You'ld think he had bin in his belley,
He's so acquainted with every cranie of his heart.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I no please me serve souche Master, a
Valet no pass vell his time vit him.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why? I have a good place on't.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Place Vat you Vill, I no be bound serve one,
I no dare tell lye to sometime.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: 'Tis somewhat a hard case, but it must be so here.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: If he send you of arrant, you stay a great vile, you no dare make excuse; extend what I mean by excuse? Sh. Ouy, ouy.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p:
I meet a friend by de Vay, I stay trink vit him a littell, one, two, three, fower howers (dat I learn in England tough)
one no dare tell souche Man, Monsieur, make me stay for one answer, yet Company come, no can write; or I cherche him in severall places, 'fore I find: call at te tailleur's, see your sute be make. An oder Man satisfie vit one of tese, he know te contrary, he no satisfie vit 'tis nor notingue else, Vich de fear of put away, or receive distribution— you understand.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Ouy, ouy. La-g. on te head and shoulders put in one Mouse; you no dare go to de Cabaret, Ven he at the Comedie, nor make good shear vit the Maids at home; no, nor goe to one bordell, Vile he at an oder.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Unless I knew he had such great business in hand, as lest him no leasure to think of me.

sp.speaker: La-g
sp.p: And so I say agen, me rader beg, steal, doe any hardeship, ten serve one Master, I no dare tell lye to.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: This necessity of speaking truth was something hard to me too at first, but I was forc'd to betake my self to't, and use, thou know'st, brings perfectness.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Dou dare not, (tough among discreet bodies, dat vill keep Counsell) tell tales of him, or recount his secrets.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: No marry, dare I not; secrecy is that he chiefly requires of a servant.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: And vat is vorse, if loosing his money, or some todre ill humeur, make him Colerick, an he Vell-come you home Vit Coups de pied.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: How now? La-g. or one good soufflet, or two.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Nay, nay; one's enough.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Dere is no complaining, 'tis so mouche for you; and fear of more, you must bite your tongue, and swallow your choler, as they say in my Countrie.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I, sure enough.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vat Consolation 'tis Monsieur Sift to swear and curse at souche Master? my bones no ake more▪ Ven mong my Camarades, I can give him heartily to all te divels.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I ha' got the length of his foot now,
And seldome am in this predicament.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Besides he's good condition'd.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Good or bad, one fair morning I vould
Pack up my nawles and be gone for all date.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Would not he know my mind, and so prevent me, had I any such intention?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vhy dere's todre ting I no speak. You no dare runne vaye neider, no dare tink of it, nor find one oder Master in secret, if dis fall out vis you.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: 'Tis a common trick indeed of servants, that grow wearie of one Master, to have another in reserve:

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Like Women who (for fear of wanting) provide a second husband, before the first be dead; but that Providence We are debarr'd of too.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: An odre incommodite I no reckon, an te gran incommodite of all; how you pick up money in 'tis service? a Man gett no more but bare vages? Pewh! it is no Vorth Vile, I should be sorrie to rob any bodie; begarre I make conscience of dat: but if Largent go torow my hands, 'tis like meal, flower, Vat you call? someting stick, stick still to de fingers.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Ah sirrah! you go snip i' your Master's money then, you take toll, you black Miller, you, you more Vnavoidable thief then his Worship's tailour.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: You make a Conscience of robbing, but you filch, you pilfer▪ you purloin unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Thou hast a fine time on't, that we want; and Enjoy'st a revenue, We dare not pretend to.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: My Master hates theft beyond imagination, and I think that for a Tester (merciless as he is) he could find in's heart to have us taught to dance in a rope.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I'm sorrie for thy sake thou camest to him, since thou art given that way; for finding it out (as doubtless he would by thy looks) he may very well tell thy Master.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Tell my Master? oh me lost, me lost! vat I doe?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Why, thy worst is but to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: And is no dat bad enofe, my friend?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Perhaps thou mayst be quit for a singing
Or so: thou canst read?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p:
Yes, yes; if he did need to know one name, to tell one's fortune, or doings, denne me attrappe him very vell, for La-gripe no me true name, me take datte, because me Vould gripe vell good moneys here, and leave my own name Vit my Countrie,
for one blow I doe, how you call? a ting, Vich make me leave France; I no come into England, no, vitte Sr Christophore else.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Though he could not; yet knowing our names y'have told all this to, he cannot when his list but know what has past amongst us.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: How could he else discover to the full what concerns him, or me: thou shalt find no ease on that side neither.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: No, no; We'l keep his fears up to the height still.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Dat very true too; but my goode Sift, if it be possible, make he no tell.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hast thou filcht soundly?

sp.speaker: La g.
sp.l: Not mouch at a time.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: But often?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Teuenty or tirty a monts, but littell, littell everie one, dat he no find: you call at Sessions Pettie Larcenie.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Then a whipping perchance may serve.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: A Vippingue? vhy many littell tefts no amount to a great teft.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: But they make thee a great thief;
And may mount thee to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Saving that, I know no way but one.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Oh goode Sifte, tell dat toder vay, I take dat rader.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: My Master's head's so full now thou mayest get out of town, and he ne're mind thee; go thy wayes then presently, and pack up; if the old Knight should hear of thy pranks, he'l not send into France after thee.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: If I be dere once, I no care dis for him; but I no dere yet.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Fetch but thy things, We'l set thee going.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: 'Tis great vay.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Were't further yet, We'l have thee thither to day.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: But thou must be well provided against the cold; there blow certain winds at Sea, thou wilt not like.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Vat? at Mid-summer?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I; as hot as 'tis at Land.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: That's the onely inconvenience of the Journey,
But thou'lt be over in a hower or two.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p:
I feare no Vindes nor Veader; I feare my Master
more, and dine too: but how I be carried?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: At ease, as e're thou wert.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Meet me in thy Master's garden,
I'le be there presently.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Let it be no long present, nor no perhaps.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Be you but ready.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: If you no come, me very angry.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I will come, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: He's o'th' house of the Credulous too:

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I'th' Lime alreadie, boy.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: There let him flutter.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: BEllamy, I have been seeking you;

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Me Sir? I have my wish if I can serve you;
Lay your commands upon me.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: A Courteous Gentleman, and a handsome one!
Who would take him for a Pick-pocket now
By his looks? but fronti nulla sides.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What means he talking to himself to eye
Me thus? has he already discover'd
Our Love, the art We us'd to hide it too?
Cruel fates! so speedie in your malice?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Foolish man that I am! I can scarce find in my aside. heart to speak to him now, I would not shame him quite; I must dissemble, and pretend that some other way my ring is faln into his hands. To be brief with you, there is a certain Jewel wanting, a small toy a ring, or so, and I am told, you have it.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.l: How soon are all my hopes blasted?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: How he is struck? his very Countenance pleads guilty.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: This the fair success I flatter'd my self with?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: I do not say, Bellamy, you are faulty,
But the party you have it by.

sp.speaker: Bellamy,
sp.l: With what obstinacy are we persecuted?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Trouble not your self; 'tis the hand alone
You have it from is guilty;
You are otherwise justifiable enough.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I have the Diamond, Sir, I can't denie't,
And here am ready to restore it you.
Y'are prepossest, I fear, by some, with a
False story of the meanes I wrought it by;
But if truth may be heard, as sure it ought
In spight of their insinuations, the guilt
Is all mine, I have no Complices;
Rather die, then Peach Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: I seek to excuse him, and he fondly accuses himself

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: Let's clear her, all we can. I tell you, Sir,
What e're y'have heard, I am in all the fault,
Nor do I plead ought to attenuate.—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: How strangely does a guilty Conscience wring him?
I palliate his fault, he exaggerates it.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: I seek not therefore to attenuate
A Crime, which when I first design'd.—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: I am not ignorant of the Fact, Bellamy, set no misseeming gloss upon't, I know the naked truth; but though I do, the knowledge of it shall not hurt you.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: There's no dissembling with you then;
Plain-dealing, now is best I do confess.—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Oh, Do you so, Sir? Do you so? but look to't another time; for, Confess and be hang'd, D'ee mark? that's the Word.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: I do confess my furtive actions then,
My Stealth, my Clandestine approaches, and
The surprizal▪ of a Jewel, which I see,
I am in your opinion too
Unworthy of: 'tis true, I am too bold,
Nor can I ought in my defence now plead:
'Twas the predominance of some ill Star
I'le say, since it brings your displeasure,
Forc'd me to what is past.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: I am not so severe a Judge neither;
I have been young my self, and can not now
Be ignorant what youth is subject to;
And some occasions seem to force our will,
Such powerful allurements they tempt it with.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: Yet though my indesert seem to forbid
All hope of pardon, by your own goodness
Sir, I dare Conjure you.—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I am merciful, I tell you,
And can excuse: having my Ring too, I
May hold my peace; 'tis an ordinary course
When a Man has his Good's again,
To wave the prosecution.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: I must not lose this opportunity,
I shall not take him in the mood agen.
Since you with so much goodness can excuse,
Be good still, Sir, and to justifie me
Thoroughly, Authorize my crime,
And give Clarinda leave
To crown my passion with approv'd consent;
Permit me, Sir, to Marry her.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Marry my Daughter? for what acquaintance troe?
The Man's mad sure, or I am mad my self;
He thinks me so at least, he'd ne're talk thus else.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: Though my meanes are small, I have a heart yet,
No frowning fortune, no adversity
Can bring under; and am of a Family
From which some richer ones may receive no
Small lustre; look on me then, Sir, with eyes
Not interess'd, or greedy of more wealth;
And you will see no cause to scorn th' alliance.

sp.speaker: S Chr.
sp.l: I● cannot be in earnest sure all this,
Or with the least thought of perswading me:
Finding some danger in the Trade of Cut-Purse,
He's now fall'n to, he will grow wise, and take
I●p●a● my cost for which purpose he must
Needs marry my Daughter forsooth; this is
One of the finest Fooles.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: He's something long-a-considering on't.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Let him steal, let him pick, let him cut, as many aside Purses, or Pockets, as he please; let him be hang'd too, and he will, he'l not disoblige me in't at all: but for Marrying my Daughter, Pardonnez moy, Monsieur; well, Bellamy, I promise you, what ever you have said.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Your Daughter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Secresie, Sir, secresie; I'le keep your Counsel,
And that's no small curtesie, I hope.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: Was ever Man in such a maze as I?
His fav'rable construction of what's past,
Seemes to invite a full Confession:
And when he knowes my passion for his daughter,
He promises secresie, and cries, he
Will keep Counsel. 'Tis the crossest this of
All my cross fortunes.
This importune Woman is another;
Let's give her the slip.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Stay, Bellamy, and be civil at least,
If you cannot be kind.
Is that heart then I have so long thought mine
An others Captive now?
Inconstancie and breach of Faith, it seemes,
Are pleasing grown to him, so often Vow'd
The Vertues contrary; the change it self
Is ordinary enough, nor am I
The first forsaken she.
But yet to shun a sight, you once
Swore, pleas'd you 'bove all others, is too strong
An effect, methinks, of a new passion;
'Tis past indifferencie this, even to scorn;
You might remember that you lov'd me once.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: Say, I esteem'd you, Madam: Love
In the respects I paied you, had least share;
My obligations t'ee were great,
And so I strove to bear a mind
Full of resentments for your noble favours,
A grateful, though not passionate heart.
But 'tis no time for such disguises now,
'Tis fit each action wear it's proper name,
Own it's true motive;
Lay your credulity then aside,
For love has bound me in those fetters now,
Must ne're be cut but with my thread of life.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: With what art this studied declaration
In such ambiguous tearmes is couch'd,
It may be made for me as for another?
He neither nam'd Celia, nor Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: 'Tis as plain though, he meanes her, as if he had.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: But you are so credulous, as he tells you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This night I waited on you by your own appoinment, what my reception was, you cannot have forgot, th' affront was to premeditate; you could not afford me one serious word, no, nor your eare a minute: think not the return I make you strange then, nor wonder, that I shun you now, as you did me; t'was your command I should, and I obey you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: He's in love w'ee, you will believe it still?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: He does, he does love me, I tell thee, strangely.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: 'Tis strangely indeed, if he loves at all;
And as strangely he shewes it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis but a triall when he slights me thus,
'Tis then he loves me passionately;
This sense of my odd carriage in the night
Is most becoming, and I take it kindly:
We're indifferent to him, he would mind it less,
Loving me, as he does, he must resent it thus.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: With an other, you see, he does himself
Confess he is in love.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: For tryal still, I tell thee, he affects
Inconstancie, as he does scorn;
And for revenge perphaps a little too
He seekes to vex me thus; all's dissembling,
Nor does he strive to make me Jealous, but
To discover at full the kindness I have
For him; 'tis that, I see, he aimes at,
Endimion told me 'twould be so.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Nay, for him, he's a cheat, I'm sure, what ever the other be.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: He has abus'd you, Madam, all-a-long,
His predictions are meere fictions,
Meere impostures.
sp.p: You might (but that you were before you spoke with him, strangely perswaded of his skill) have seen it in his whole proceeding.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: He but deludes you with vain hopes,
Bellamy does forsake you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Can you be ignorant he adores Clarinda?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Gratian assures you of it too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I trust not to what Gratian sayes; he has
Cast off all thoughts of friendship, and without
The least regard to Bellamy, or his love,
Is hourely troubling me with his own,
You see he is.
I give no credit to a Rivall's story.
For whatso're of Bellamy he sayes,
I've cause to fear, but reason still to doubt.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Rather believe him, Madam; for you'l find
Gratians Story is a true one. His love
Though violent, can hear some reason yet,
And keep within the bounds of honour; think
Not then, he seekes by treachery to win you,
By base suggestions to supplant his friend.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: While I thought him worthy of you,
Or could on any grounds believe him yours,
What did I, Madam, or what said I, to
Cross your fair affections?
I was all friend then, mov'd not one step
Out of my Confident's path, for him was
All I spoke, my own cause I pleaded but
With silence, allow'd it not the least complaint,
But what was fair from reaching him, or you;
Or if some time a sudden sigh broke through
The care I us'd to keep 'em in, how soon
Like to some blusht-at, or unlawful issue,
Did I disavow it, nay, lay it to
Another? but the concealment
Of my sufferings and his injuries t'ee,
Would not a kindness now to Bellamy prove
That false Bellamy?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How loth am I yet to believe him such?
Can he be false to Celia, that thought so
Well of him? She that so truely lov'd him?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: 'Tis strange a heart once yours, should ever own
An other Conqueror: but he is false, false
To the fairest Celia, false, as miserable
In this Exchange.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Bellamy forsakes me?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Perhaps 'tis with regret, a sharp remorse
Perhaps poysons all the sweets he leaves you Sir
Yet he forsakes you still; and with his own
Consent I tell you so.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And 'tis Clarinda
Robs me of this beloved Perjurer?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: But now We left him at Sr Christopher's.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: And least we should mistake him any longer
Gratian, (cryed he to me, as he went in)
I know your passion, and cease t'oppose it,
I quit all claim to Celia; for if love
Have happiness for me, 'tis in Clarinda's Armes.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: May I believe all this?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: A greater truth ne're challeng'd your beliefe.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Alas! he never left the town, but lurk'd
At my house for private meetings
With Clarinda, whom he saw night by night.
A truth though, no Interest of my own
Had e're extorted, did not yours claim it,
And his allowance Manumize the secret.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No more; my doubt is over, and the mist
Love cast before my eyes thus vanisht, more
Hatesul, as more hated does he appear,
Then ever he seem'd lovely, nor was my
Affection ever half so strong, as now
My anger is▪ Gratian, do you love me?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Oh Madam!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How can I ever believe Man agen,
When Bellamy is false? yet follow me,
If your affection be sincere, as you
Protest; Celia is yours; but bring me to
Clarinda's, and make my own eyes witness
His crime, that I may do you Justice there
Before his face; serve my anger so farre,
And second the revenge I do intend,
That he may see himself forsaken, as he
Forsakes, and there (if I may have my wish)
Shall he repent his perjurie,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: That I believe too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yet all in vain.
Lost to all hopes of e're recovering
What he so basely does renounce; there let
Him pine to find me in another's arms,
And without hopes of either Mistress, see
Clarinda scorn him, as he now does me.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: A fine humour this, Luce;

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: An 'twould hold.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh, it must hold.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Whether Love will or no?

div.head: SCENE II. Sir Christopher 's Garden.
div.stage: Enter La-gripe in a travelling habit.

sp.p: A Dieu, London, adieu; I goe see my own naturall Contree agen: an France be ne're so bad, or England so good, better be alive dere, den hang here.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: How now, art readie?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Dou seest, te good Capotte, Vit my bottes ala Candalle

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: 'Tis well, 'tis well, thou hast clad thy self warm; the Journey's something bleak, as I told thee.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I putt tis hood over my face, for fear te cold, and some todre ting make me loose my nose quite.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I think indeed 'tis something loose set on.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Zymar, Haly, Behemoth, Albenzera.
Get into this Circle.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Vat dou Mumble, mumble in te teeths?
Say te divells Pater noster, I tinke.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Words of art, words of art: but 'tis done alreadie. Thou must be hoodwink'd now.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Pourquoy?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: There are reasons for't, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Your Jockeys, I hear say, ride temself blind,
But for uate I be make blinde, before I ride.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: With the great light, and that prodigious height thou wilt be mounted to thy eyes would be dazled, and thou giddily come tumbling down.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Who knows too how near thou mayest come to the Sun, thy Lids would not save 'em from scorching then, nor the distillations still overflowing quench the fire.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: That brinie dew would add more furie to't.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Then thy nose would melt off indeed,
But this muffler saves all.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Indeed me have grand distraction, to see all te Vorld at one time, I can no hinder my self from be peeping in every corner; I tinkue I mind me business better, and see notinge, deresore blinde me, I am content: but how I ride? Vat be carried on? uere dat?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I need but whistle, and 'tis here.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Is it a saddel horse, or one Coche?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: No, no; a pad-nag.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: A bad nag? begare me uill have a good nag, or no goe at all your Vay.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Thou shalt have a good one;
I say, a pad-nag, a fine gentle pacer.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Oh crie you mercie, Vnderstand now; my Master ride souche one himself, 'tis very easie for us olde Men: but Vho be my guide? Vat if I loose my vaie? it very like; for I no travell dat rode before.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: There's a question indeed! thou shalt have a little Orenge-tawny devill to lacquey by thy side.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: A divell lacquey? I no hear of souch before.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Why, half the lacqueys about the town are devils, Man, and in thy Country they are ten times worse.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Dat's true indeed; but I always hear say, te divell uery proud, and tink he no take so mean place.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Some of 'em I grant are above it, but there are enow to supply all places, and he will put on any shape, rather then not make one.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Which is to play at small game, rather then sit out.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Shall I tell thee? there are devils of all functions and qualities, trades and callings whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Alas, the Mysterie of every trade is knavery,
And that leads directly to him.
There are Sergeants, and Bailiff-divils.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: And divillishly are they us'd, when they meddle with a guard-man, or any of the Boulley Rocks indeed.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Some neat, dapper, well-handed fiends are cut out into Barbers, Tire-women, and Valets de chambre;

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Of which there come such shoules out of thy Country:

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Your nimbler handed ones make Tailors, and Weavers.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Thieving devils: he devils, and she devils.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Vat Voman divels?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Oh sans nombre: and they make cuckolds.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Te divell Cuckold too?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: How should he come by his horns else?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: And for more fiendly variety, there are sage devils, and mad devils; hectoring devils, and cowardly devills; quaking devils—

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Yes, in frost and snoe; I have bin such one my self, before I come to good Anglish Cole fires.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: But these quake now, at Midsummer.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Begare trowe 'em in te river, and make
Quake for some ting.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Come, thou stay'st a devilish while here,
'Tis time thou wert goue.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: There are water-devils too; but those we call dippers.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Rumpers and thumpers. Raw. Zealous and impious.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Precise and prophane.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Merry devils, and very devils, commonly known by the name of Phanaticks.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: But thine's come; get up, get up.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Oh undoe, undoe; I see if mine be a horned divell; your men Cuckolds hide teir horn so, you no see a great manies; I long to see how te divell wear his.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: 'Twere worth seeing indeed: but let everie Cuckold wear his own horns, and as he pleas himself: this is a batchelor devil; one though that having no apes to lead in hell, comes to lead a baboon into France.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Vat's dat? Vat's dat? I have great Curiosity
To look him in face.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Take heed, 'tis dangerous; he has a more dreadful countenance ten times then thy old Master.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Gare, and he one I no mouche care for see now.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: 'Tsufficient he conduct thee into France;
Then see him, and spare not.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I look him out of Countenance, Ven I am dere.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Come, get up, get up.

div.stage: horses him on a rail or hedge with a cushion under him.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vell Monsieur te divell, do not quitte me, Ven you get me in one strange place, bring me safe in my countree, and den I can doe vell enof vit oute you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Ne're fear him, he'l not leave thee so,
Thou art too good a bit for him.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: For Vat you tie so hard, Master Sift?
is it you, or te divell?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: He's afraid thou wilt slip from him.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: No, no, I varrant's you, if he no run
Way from me.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: If he does, ride after him;
Thou art damnably well mounted.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Is't easier now?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I, I, now 'tis vell; but vho vntie me, Vhen I come home, I can no doe't my self, I no see.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: It shall be done to thy hand,
When thou art at thy Journey's end.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: O Sift, Sift, I forgot; Vill tis Jade carrie in crouper, Vat you call in England? double, double, carrie double?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Why doe'st ask?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I take my felloe Beatrige along Vit me, she ride behind; very good companie for te divell, and for me too, very good in te vay.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Yes, too good for thee, old Jew; what ride double? aside. to him. No, no, ride post to th' devil, the old saying is; I could have order'd it so, she might have gone too; but 'tis too late now, and thou must take the Journey single, as thou art.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vell, vell, 'tis no matter; I get an odre in France.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: By this token know thou art within ken; a doleful Voyce thou shalt first hear; at thy arrival, wrangling or confused talk, then lowder Lamentations; but fare thee well, set forward.

sp.speaker: Raw.
