sp.l: Commend us to our friends in Paris.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Yes, yes; dat I vill.
sp.stage: in a hollow tone as from a farre

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Adieu, Monsieur La-gripe, adieu.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Adieu, La-gripe, adieu; with what speed thou flyest?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: How he cleaves the air? he's gone, hes gone;
I can scarce discern him now.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p:
I doe perceive I fly very fast indeed, for now I hardly
hear teir Voice, my Eares take but te last Accents, as of one very remote.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: A right Frenchman! bread in's pocket;

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Where's the Cheeze?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Oh, that's at his Toes to haut-goust.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Which he calls refining.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I be in France presant, I drink good Claret Vine, pure, pure; no mingle mangle, red and white, as here in England.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Do, fuddle thy Nose, and if they pick thy pocket I'le pay the reckoning.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I take Sift for one little Quenave,
And he prove honest little Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Yes, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Rawman too, very well vers'd, experienc'd—

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: In thy Pockets.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Te beast tey set me upon, go as easie
Too, as no stir at all.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: If it does, they are mistaken.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: No shake, shake me; need no spur neider.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: The ill manner'd Jade would hardly answer to't.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I be as still as in me Bed, sure I very good Horseman.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: For the Woodden-Horse.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I no loose in te Saddel.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Nor in the Hilts?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: 'Tis very holesome air, I grow very hungry.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: You stuff'd your Pockets, as if y'had known you should—

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: But Vat Vind tis? stinking Vind too,
sp.stage: R. Biows in's face with a pair of bellows.
sp.l: Tell me dere blow,
One Vind very cold, and so 'tis indeed,
I see he know all tings in te vay, as
He go it himself.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: An other gale, an other gale.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Te Vind turn; sure my Beard freeze wit tis blow, blow. I fear my Nose too for all tis good Capotte, I no dare feel how tis neider.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: There's company come in to th' garden,
We must away.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Jog on, jog on good Antiquity.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Y'are almost at your Journeyes end.

div.stage: Enter Bellamy, Clarinda with a thin hood on.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Discover'd already? So soon betray'd
Unto my Fathers knowledge?
What hard fates, Bellamy, attend our Loves?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You stand yet▪ blameless in your Father's eye;
I wholly drew the Crime upon my self,
And rather chose to pass for a suborner,
Then you should forward seem, in the disposal
Of that he claimes it is his right to give.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: No, no; We do but fool our selves with hopes,
There is no ground left for that self-flatterie.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Soon as he tax'd me with the Ring, I rendred it,
That precious pledge of thy unmatch'd affection:
Let not thy griefe precede our misery though,
He neither shew'd, nor threatned any rigour,
He spoke but in his wonted tone, rather
Amaz'd then angry, and us'd me (trust me
Sweet he did) with much mildness still; and seem'd
(By arguing the business with himself)
Something irresolute what course to take;
And I dare hope, if from thy self he hear
Thou doest affect me, it may incline him
To allow thy choice.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I that will doe't, I'le dry my eyes agen,
We'l nere be wretched sure, when speaking truth
Can make us happy. If this may win him,
Clarinda's yours; once more I tell you so.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: VVhat grief is proofe against this joy?
Or what misery has a name, which these words
Clarinda's mine, would not charm into happiness?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'm yours for ever, or no Man's; he that can debarr me of this felicitie, shall not add to my affliction, being an others.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Such bliss in silence still is best receiv'd,
I want words to give full thankes.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I understand some noise of Tongues, some People talking a great way of, sure I ride over some great City; Is it Canterbury? no, no, I hope I be pass te Seas.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How now? Is there any body come in?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Oh yes, Sir Christopher, and the Astrologer forsooth; he's no body without him now: he was wont to dote upon wealth, and then our House was nothing but Aldermen, and Citizens, that write themselves Esquire, and Country Knights, that never came to Town, but for a new Purchase: but that fit's over now, and learning is his bable.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: They interupt us too soon, I would not
Have him see you yet, Endimion being with him too.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Can I not slip out?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No, I know his walkes, he uses at his entrance to take that, should now lead you out; but step aside, ith' close walk he'l not discover you: and there, if boldly speaking in our cause may carry it, you'l hear me plead for you as you were here your self.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You are all goodness, Madam.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Good Devil, look to me, if I be at Sea, for I can no swimme.

div.stage: To them Sr Christopher Credulous, Endimion, Bernard, Shift.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: A most delicious garden this!

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: 'Tis my Whore, Sir, 'tis my Whore;
Here I delight, and consume my self.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: That's e'en a Whore's trick indeed

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Here, Clarinda, here's thy Ring again.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Must I endure that object in my Eye?

div.stage: To B. pulling down her hood. Turning it up.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: What so coy, Mistress? Will you not parley unveil'd?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The Sun's too hot, Sir, I never walk in't
Without my Hood, I shall be tann'd.

sp.speaker: S ● Chr.
sp.p: And you be, and you be, 'tis but one Takes it quite off. lick more, you have that in your Closet, I know, can fetch it off again; here Gentlewoman, Throwes it Beat. that belongs to your care.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: I long'd to see how Clarinda did behave her To Bern. self after all these odd accidents, and how she'ld look upon me.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: She's too much discompos'd;

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: She is, and I too well reveng'd; I pity her.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: 'Tis not a civil wellcome this, of a person thou art so lately, and so much oblig'd too; 'tis to him thou art engag'd for the recovery of thy Ring; I thought thou would'st have slown into his armes, had help'd thee to't again, thou wert so lost for want of it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Gladly into his, that had it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Your Father, Madam, is pleas'd to name an Obligation So slight, I dare not think it one.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Tis one indeed, she con's you little thanks.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But if kind Heaven prosper what I intend,
A solid and important service shall
Prove the Zeal I have to please you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You have already, Sir, oblig'd me, more
Then I can thank you for.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: By te different noises I find I pass from place to place; and now I tink I am at Callais; gare te Steeples, if I be.

div.stage: To them Gratian, Lewis, Celia, Fannie, Luce,

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Here's more Company, What Ladie's that? or what would she?
She lookes with an earnest, and a busie face.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: With an angry one, methinks.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Tis a pretty little angry Rogue,
Would I had the pleasing of her.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: You please her? please me? and hear the Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Wonder not Sir, at so abrupt a visit,
I come for Justice t'ee; We are both wrong'd,
Both abus'd by one unconstant Man; one
That when a thousand Oathes had made him mine,
Your Daughter has stoln from me; nay, start not,
She loves him infinitely; he nere had left
Me for an unkind one, no, no they burn
In mutual flames; and in your house, or Garden
Is he now conceal'd, now, this very minute:
Do me reason then, and your self Justice.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I wish he be here, for I begin to fear,
Finding Clarinda without him.

sp.speaker: La g.
sp.p: Sure tis is te doleful Voice, te lamentation; good sign, good sign, I be almost come home.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: How! a man hidden in my house? a plot, a plot; fetch me my rapier there, I'le poak him out of his hole; a plot upon my daughter.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Your daughter's plot upon you rather.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis an increase of miserie this, I never fear'd;
She's very handsome; what then? nay, I think
Bellamy did love her once; no matter:
Coming just i'th' nick too, when he is here,
Silence my Jealousie,
I've trouble enough without thee.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Pox of this bussle, 'twill land our Travellour too soon.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My father, I hope, suspects not me
In any close contrivance—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Nay, nay, 'tis best for you be clear; I will think well o' thee so long as I may; but if thou bee'st faulty, th hast lost a f iend of me: I le rage no higher, till I see th'accusation prov'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Poor Clarinda!
With what increase of trouble I see thine?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: They are all to pieces now indeed.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I have a soder for em yet.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I am come home sure, I hear such confused tones, and lamentable voices.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Come, Madam, first let's make the garden sure,
This way— hah! what have we here?
This is a skare-crow—

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Tis is te very noise, Sift tell me of; divell, divell, Vere be you, my Lacquey-divell? untie, untie me.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: What Pageant's this: 'tis La-gripe's dialect.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Tis our Travellour, Sir.
He thinks himself in France alreadie.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: A hasty Monsieur indeed; but
'Tis no time for this mirth now: help him down.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Now I be come, now I be come; never make being got off. Journey vit so much ease. O my Moder Earth, I must kiss dee for Joy.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Why how now?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: You be got into my Country too? but ease me of one scruple, how you come? he lend you one pad-nag too? vat co▪ lour your Vorship's divell? mine Orenge-tawny, dat his colours of old, you know: I dare swear now my Master's be one aside. horned fiend and dat I fear is horn to horn.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: He's mad sure; see where thou art, in London,
In my garden; see thy young Mistress too, Beatrix.—

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Begare I be so indeed. I be base besheat, stares about him gets up, searches his pockets. my purse gone into France, or some Vere else ah dou dog-rogue Sift, I have thee by the ears present.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: If the devil pick thy pocket, can I help it?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: This is not the conceal'd Lover, you mean, Madam;
'Tis a disguiz'd one rather I think this.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I look after no such mouldy ware, Sir.
'T was not this. I hope, you brought me to see.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Madam you'l find things yet, as I gave 'em out t'ee.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If they would search no further now.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You'l pardon, Sir, my Man's boldness, I hope,
That plays the knave thus with yours.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: 'Tis easily pardon'd to preserve your friendship:
But to our other business, our serious trouble.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: They turn this way; better shew my self,
Then be found sneaking here.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: Let's seek this way.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Seek him no further, Madam, here he is.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Ungrateful, faithless Man!

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Hah! Is it he?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: You perjur'd man, you; have we found you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Nay, never rail, nor throw at me those undeserv'd
Reproaches; there is a Ladie here, can vouch my constancie.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: What Planet was my Girl born under troe?
I seek her Lover, and find a thief, a Pick-pocket.
sp.p: You lay perdu upon some new design now, there are more Jewels in the house, Cabinets unrifled; I pray God there be. Ent. Shift again. This is their trick to a hair; slip in th' dusk of the Evening, and when we are all fast, open the doors to an inundation of Vermin. A pox on this thieve's handsel, I knew there was worse to follow.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: The Man's beside himself sure, to wrong a Gentleman thus barbarously; though I have reason not to think him innocent, yet I dare pawn my life, the base guilt you charge him with, is none of's crime. What mean you then by this abusive Language?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Alas! he understands me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Not very well, Sir.
What draws this scandalous reproach?
I am no thief, my Enemie, I dare swear,
If I have any, will answer for me:
My mind is set on nobler objects farre,
My name and family free from the least stain
Of such ignoble ways; nor have you ought
In all your vast possessions I value,
But your daughter.
'Tis her I love, this year and more she has
Bin Mistress of my life and hopes; the Ring
You tax'd me with, from her hand I newly
Had receiv'd: and if the sternness of a
Father's brow fright not a timerous Maid from
Free discoverie of such thoughts, ask her, and
What she makes not good of all my storie,
Repute me lyer in; a name
I would not for your wealth deserve.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Speak, Clarinda, saies he true? do'st love him?
Speak boldly, and the truth, what ere it be,
It shall be welcome to a father's ear.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Heaven knows I need not blush to own it,
And yet I doe, I love him, Sir,
And have done this—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Nay, nay, then the rest is plain enough: well
We must make the best of a bad market.
Endimion your advice.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Nere advise with him, he's a mere impostor.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Now will he raise a new storm.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Never fear him, his Astrologie's well worn out by this.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Let my Ponyard prevent his malice.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: He's born to be hang'd I see; because he proves no thief, he'l commit murder.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Celia's yours, I tell you; Endimion
Has no love for Clarinda, I know he has not.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: That assurance revives me.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Assist me now, kind Stars,
To put a period to these Lovers paines,
And I'le nere trouble you with an other Suit.

sp.speaker: S Chr.
sp.l: My honour lies at state; what shall I doe?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: A fatal chain these several accidents
Are link'd together in, no breaking;
Yeild, yeild to what heaven has decreed, and
Is indeed above halfe done to your hands;
These Lovers were made for one another,
I almost told you so before, in the
Description of the Man she is ordain'd for;
And since one rich in Vertue, not in Land,
Must be your Son in Law, where could you better choose,
Frank Bellamy is nobly bred, as born:
Give free consent then to their happiness,
Let it a fruit of your indulgence to 'em,
And not a forc'd allowance now appear;
That mingled with the joyes we shall wish them,
Our thankes to you on their behalf may flow.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Well, what must be, must be; I cannot fail however in following that path Heaven has trac'd out for me. Bellamy, I embrace you as my Son, my Daughter's yours.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And I for ever to your goodness bound.
Oh my Clarinda, now y'are mine indeed.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is it thus you keep your promise, Sir Christopher?
This the Justice I look'd for?
My honour suffers still.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: There was no other salve for mine; and Charity begins at home, good Lady; remember that still. As much reason, for ought I know, to Marry, as to Christen my own Child first.

sp.speaker: Cel. to Bell.
sp.l: to goe, follow that misleading light,
Triumph in thy inconstancy, and let
Thy now-Mistress taste of it in time too;
'Tis that, 'tis that will do me right.
Come, Gratian, I'le keep my word with you;
We'l streight to Church.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Most willingly; sweet Lady, I must take her i'th' fit.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: 'T would soon be over else.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, let's not part in anger, Madam; there
Are Weddings towards, We should be friends,
And merry then; Lewis call Gratian back.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: A Woman's anger is soon over.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: And a Lad's Love as soon out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Or let it last, who cares?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Or the other, who's the better for't?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Come, let's hear now, what fine new device you stay me for; Oh! you are a sweet Gentleman, to pass for an Astrologer, and have no more skill then my Chambermaid, or Fannie there.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Truely nor so much, for we began to smell him out.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: When the fit takes you next to make love, Sir,
Trust to your merit, and not your science,
That you see has deceiv'd you; the match is made now
You set all your Engines a work to break.
How shallow is this art you brag'd of?
Or, How little are you vers'd in't?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You told me 'twas but to make trial of me,
Bellamy courted Clarinda, and that
'Twas I he lov'd, when the first sight of him
Proves the contrary; the Stars lend you but
A dimme light, it seemes, that can no better
Read our destiny by it.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Did you not perswade me too, that Celia
Ceas'd to love Bellamy? when Heaven knowes
What torture the continued expressions
Of her kindness to him, have put me to.
Burn your bookes, Sir, burn your bookes for shame,
Your lying bookes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Tis well for him now, I nere was curious
Enough to peep into my destiny,
Nor given that inquisitive way;
I must have had a fling at him too,
Which needes not; there are male-contents enow
To worrie him without me.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: If te Damoisells have done vit teir tale, please you have mine, It is a foul tale, I assure you, of accusation against tis Astrolog too, Did you no promise send me into France fine new way, and me be here in London still? I be Judge by all te Company, if me no here: and vat is very worse, you say I go wit out Robbing, and begare me loose my Purse.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Your grievance is of weight indeed.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Of veight? gare my grievance be, you make me lighter by all my Money.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That's easily redress'd, give him his Purse agen;
And no more of these slippery trickes.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Twas but a trick of wit, Sir;
I hope you'l remember the Ensurer, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Yes, I assure you one halter, if you play more such trick of vit.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Now to my pretty chiders:
For even in that, Ladies, you upbraid me with,
Have I matter enough to make my peace.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: With help of some strange hard non sence,
Your Worship's tearmes of Art.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: In plain English, but first your pardon, Sir,
That I durst play the Astrologer with you,
When nere in all my Studies, nor my Travells
I spent a serious minute to become one.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: You are no Astrologer then?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: None, in good sooth, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: You told me so before indeed;
Though my itch of Learning would not let me
Credit it: but now I do believe you▪
He'd nere degrade himself in publick thus,
Could he maintain the height
My credulity had rais'd him to.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: And thus may you the better now forgive
The error y'have been in, that still were deaf
To whatsoere I said to disabuse you.
If sooner, Madam, then you durst expect,
A Father's liking crown your Love, and his,
You may thank me for't; your match had nere been
Clapt up thus o'th' sudden, had he not on my
Insinuation believ'd it made in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Truth, I think it had not.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nor have I done less for you, if well consider'd,
Was it fit so fair a stock of beauty
Should lie begging of a beggar still?
I ve plac'd you where you'l brightest shine,
VVhere love with interest will be paid you back,
Kiss for kiss were poor retaliation.
Bellamy, whom I saw adore Clarinda,
VVas not an Idol fit for you to worship;
While Gratian's heart became a burning sacrifice
VVith fire shot from your killing eyes.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Now he tickle's her.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: She'l forgive all her enemies
For such another clawing speech.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Let them complain that suffer, I have my wish;
Nor is your share, I see, so small in the
Procurement of't, but it has made me yours.
I might have percht in Gratian's Cock-loft still,
But for Astrologie.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: As you have made me no less happie, with
As sincere affection, I vow my self
Your servant: yet let me tell you,
I began to think there was not
Much Astrologie i'th' business neither,
What ever we conceited of you.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Happiness, Gentlemen, is happiness still,
I take it, which way so ere arriv d at.
Something in every design we stalk with
To take the Vulgar eye, when that which does
The work indeed, being unperceiv'd,
It often is ascrib'd to a wrong Cause.
I design'd both these matches, Lewis and
Bernard there can witness for me,
And to your joyes and mine I see 'em made,
Be it with real or fained skill in
What I took upon me, that matter's not.
The pleasures you reap from it are no fictions,
That we all see.
And I expect my thanks accordingly.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: And you, Sir travellour, that were promis'd you should not be robb'd by the way; prythee, how couldst, if thou hadst gone thy Journey, when I had secur'd thy money here before?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vell, vell, vit one bottle or two de Vine, tis shall be satisfaction; and sirrahs, keark you, no tell my master, you know vat.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: No, no; we would not hang thee.

sp.speaker: Glar.
sp.p: Bellamy might think that were not my felicitie, he has acknowledged you a furtherer of, did I not pay my thanks too; you have oblig'd us both, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: If my Compliment be somewhat colder, Sir, then others you have had from this thankful Companie, impute it to a certain blindness, allows me not yet a full view o'th' happiness y'have plac'd me in; but as my sense of it increases, so shall my Gratitude.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: I would fain thank you too, Sir; but truly I m beholding t'ee for nothing, but frighting me with the vision of Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Now for our squeakers.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p:
Why I pass'd for an Astrologer, or how, without being one,
I knew enough of your adventures to make th' opinion good a while, Beatrix can partly tell.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: The distaff was of Counsel.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: The rest may better come from Lewis there, or Bernard; and be part of their Apologie.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: They in th' Intrigue too?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Grand Intriguers.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: All this we'l hear at leasure; 'twill make an excellent storie, when we have it all together: but now let's in, the air grows cold, though love and youth keep you from feeling it— what fidlers?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Yes in truth, Sir; I saw there would be a Wedding or two, and made bold to invite 'em in; there's no mirth without Musick, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Why God-a-mercy; come, strike up there,
A kissing dance to please these Wenches.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A kissing dance! nay then, I will make one,
I'm resolv'd on't. Come Beatrix.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: You may dance, Sir; but we'l have no kissing,
'Tis not come to that yet.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You are not quite come to 't indeed;
But here are riper lips.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: She tells you true, Sir; 'tis not come to that yet.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Play my delight.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Thy Mistress forbids no kissing.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: No, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: She goes to't with a better stomack.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And they wont kiss
They shall dance by themselves for Shift.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: And for Beatrix too.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Brisk youths on my credit: come, to supper; nothing but welcome can I promise though o'th' sudden; but when my Girl is married
sp.l: I'le feast you all, and nobly, that are here;
So your dislike blast not our Wedding cheare.
